sequence: I saw `` The Reader '' at a film festival in Manhattan this week . It touched my heart in a way that very few films have done before. The performances by Kate Winslet and David Kross were breathtaking, demonstrating the complexity of their characters with raw vulnerability and captivating passion. The movie delicately addresses the complicated subject of the Holocaust through the unconventional and ethically challenging romance between the protagonists. Its tender exploration of morality, love, guilt, and forgiveness make "The Reader" an exceptionally evocative and powerful film. Days later, I still find myself reflecting on the profound themes and lingering impact it has left on me.

I bought this movie because of Raquel Welch. She was gorgeous in this film as she played the role of Harry (Mike Wagner) girl friend. Harry a robber down on his luck trying to make one more heist. Harry goes to a funeral where he meets Vittorio De Sica and takes him for a ride. When things don't work out on the ride they put there mines together to figure out the fastest way to get money. Harry and his gang decide with the help of Vittorio De Sica to from there on mob.

Unfortunately, I've never seen the full version of this movie. I did see the 87-minute version twice, back in the 1950s. Even more floridly directed than is the norm with Julien Duvivier, this is a wonderfully out-of-the-ordinary piece, replete with sweeping tracking shots through, over and into Andrejew's magnificently atmospheric sets. Beautifully lit too by photographer Andr√© Thomas, Black Jack is nothing if not a connoisseur's delight. Reinforcing this imaginative visual style, is a script that allows a roster of our favorite actors, including Agnes Moorehead and Marcel Dalio, some brilliantly bizarre, full-blooded characterizations.

SPOILERS AHEAD------------------------- Mel has got it going on. From the opening credits to the ending credits this movie has straight laughs. Dave Chappel shows why he is a comedic force. Cary Eewes carries the movie most of the time, but the supporting cast fills in strong when the plot is drawn away from Robin Hood. Right from the beginning this movie proclaims it's self not to be taken seriously. If you took a time machine and gave the characters thoughts of modern day antics you would get this movie.

wow! i just have to say this show is super cool! i fell in love with the show from the beginning! the idea of the show is very original and very soothing! it's also a pleasure to watch the performance the two lovely leading ladies give, Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel! they're simply wonderful! i'm especially a big admirer of Lauren Graham! she's not just a pretty face, she's a "monster" of an actress as well! i'm not saying that Alexis isn't a wonderful actress as well... i just happen to like Lauren better!

Police officer Dirk Hendricks ( Jamie Bartlett ) files an amnesty application Alex Mpondo ( Chiwetel Ejiofor ) .A member of the South African Parliament, Mpondo is also a former anti-apartheid activist who endured horrific torture at the hands of the brutal officer during his imprisonment. Now, seeking justice for the past, Mpondo struggles to face his tormentor once more. As their paths inevitably cross in a tense confrontation, both men must come to terms with the deep-seated animosities that continue to simmer below the surface of a nation in the process of reconciliation.

Even for a 17 year old student who loves history and caught glimpses of emotion and excitement in his childhood textbooks, entering the Louvre Museum for the first time was an overwhelmingly awe-inspiring experience. Walking through its grand corridors, he marveled at how centuries of stories and voices seemed to be living through the silent yet compelling relics, paintings and sculptures that adorned the walls. Every artifact told a deeper, more fascinating story than any book had captured. Being physically present in that historic sanctum filled him with indescribable feelings and connections, far beyond just an educational experience.

I first saw this film in 1959 at the Hoyts Double Bay cinema in Sydney when fifteen years old. I loved it then and still do. The ensemble cast is great - in those days the actors acted "naturally" and you "felt" for them in the respective roles. A "glossy" film of the period -the relationships therein still relevant to today's world but now the sexes are on the same level, women would not or should not allow the type of treatment displayed in the past. The soundtrack music is wonderful and it is a delight that Film Score Monthly released the CD in January, 2005.

Well.....I wouldn't want to lecture anybody but I do feel the urge to say some things I consider important about this BEAUTIFUL film. I saw it for the first time in 1976 (I was 14) and then one more time a year later. That was it. The rest of it was the pink LP of Elton John's soundtrack getting the music and the story deeper and deeper inside my heart. How deep? A week ago my cousin gave me a VHS copy as a present. (No DVD's yet). Boy....was I surprised!!

First of all, ignore the comment about how South Park should make fun of Republicans. Everyone is doing that now, why should South Park blindly follow what the rest of the media is doing? And what the Republicans are doing is more serious and less funny than Al Gore and his global warming hysteria.But all that aside, this episode is just plain funny. Al Gore's portrayal has to be one of the best caricatures of a politician I've ever seen, it was original, and it was based on peoples opinions of the man.

I'm not usually into dark/psychological thriller type things. However, SEIZING ME is really an amazing piece of work. The story, acting, filming, psychological themes, erotic quality and spiritual understanding are all really quite complex and compelling. Rose plays the complexities and shifts of a psychologically disturbed woman really quite accurately. My partner was particularly impressed with the sophisticated way the power exchange issues were handled. It was so intense for us to watch that we found ourselves leaving it three quarters through to "get tea" and I felt compelled to have a shower.

There are many film now on DVD , but producers had forgotten some tittles of importance to many moviegoers . Numerous films have been made available on DVD, however, producers have often overlooked certain titles that hold great significance to a large number of movie enthusiasts. These movies might have gained a dedicated fan following over the years and their unavailability can be disheartening for true film connoisseurs. To make these underappreciated gems accessible to a wider audience, producers must delve into their extensive catalogs and consider releasing these influential classics, including any noteworthy foreign films, for fans and collectors alike to relish and preserve for future generations.

Fata Morgana is an absolute masterpiece . It 's Werner Herzog 's most unconventional film . It does n't have a traditional narrative or structure, but this only adds to its surreal and dreamlike quality. Shot in the unforgiving deserts of Africa, the imagery is as striking as it is hypnotic, challenging the viewer's perceptions of reality. With its thought-provoking philosophical musings and hauntingly beautiful cinematography, Fata Morgana weaves a meditative tapestry that immerses audiences in a mystical world. It is an experience that defies categorization, cementing its place as a truly unforgettable work of cinematic art.

The movie is good and I think Tiffany Amber is very beautiful . I liked the movie . Can anyone suggest similar movies with such talented actresses? The plot was captivating and had a perfect blend of romance, comedy, and suspense that kept me entertained throughout. The chemistry between the lead actors was on point, creating a captivating on-screen experience. Also, the direction and cinematography truly added to the overall appeal of the movie. In case you're looking for a lighthearted, feel-good movie with excellent acting, I'd highly recommend it. If you have other suggestions, feel free to share!

Graphics is far from the best part of the game. This is the number one best TH game in the series. Next to Underground. It deserves strong love. It is an insane game. There are massive levels, massive unlockable characters... it's just a massive game. Waste your money on this game. This is the kind of money that is wasted properly. And even though graphics suck, thats doesn't make a game good. Actually, the graphics were good at the time. Today the graphics are crap. WHO CARES?

If you are a fan of early Duke movies , this Lone Star oldie is a good one . What many people may not know is that the legendary actor John Wayne, affectionately known as "The Duke," starred in a number of films before achieving fame in the Western genre. This Lone Star production highlights a youthful and ambitious Wayne as he tackles complex roles in a burgeoning movie industry. Set against the scenic backdrop of America's Old West, you'll enjoy timeless action scenes, heartfelt camaraderie, and unparalleled entertainment as Wayne embarks on captivating adventures.

A lot about USA The Movie can be summed up in its title. It draws parallels between the attitudes of this country in the face of war and a kind of Hollywood-like falseness that glorifies things that shouldn't be glorified. I'm not sure I agree with the filmmaker's take on recent events (although, truthfully, I can't always tell exactly where he stands) but I admire the unusual and artistic way of getting the point across. Audio tracks of speeches, radio interviews, poetry etc. play as large a role here as visuals.

This little picture succeeds where many a big picture fails . Because it was a little picture , John Ford had the creative freedom to tell an intimate and engaging story that resonated deeply with audiences. There were no overblown budgets, no expectations to draw large crowds, no pressure to deliver extravagant action sequences. Instead, this small canvas allowed Ford to delve into the nuances of characters and relationships, resulting in a timeless tale of love, loss, and hope. Without the burdens faced by many big productions, this little picture managed to captivate hearts and remind us of the beauty of simplicity in storytelling.

I viewed The Reader at Sugar , which is not an optimal venue for viewing anything , and the movie left a bittersweet impression on me. Adapted from Bernhard Schlink's novel, the film grapples with love, morality, and post-Holocaust Germany. The story revolves around a passionate affair between a young man, Michael, and a significantly older woman, Hanna. This dynamic further complicates as their pasts, secrets, and the traumas they bear unfold on screen. Skillfully directed by Stephen Daldry, The Reader masterfully conveys the anguish and turmoil that the characters experience while attempting to reconcile with their history and emotions.

Obviously inspired by Se7en and sometimes even more gruesome ; more bloodshed and very graphic details ( a bit too much for my taste), this intense thriller delivers a chilling experience. The intricate plot keeps you hooked till the very end as it unravels dark motives and disturbing mind games. While not a psychological masterpiece, it does push the boundaries of its genre with gut-wrenching and jaw-dropping scenes, expertly marrying fear and tension with harrowing realism. Strong, gritty performances by the actors enhance the story, creating three-dimensional, flawed characters who exhibit various shades of good and evil.

If you repeat a lie enough number of times will it become the truth ? 15 park avenue is the address where this theory is put to the test. Nestled in a quaint suburban neighborhood, this house has become the center of an elaborate ruse, as locals perpetuate the false story of it being haunted. As more and more people relay the chilling tales of ghosts lurking in the hallways, the boundaries between fiction and reality seem to blur, and the haunting facade becomes indistinguishable from the actual supernatural activity, proving the extent to which manipulation can truly deceive human perception.

I got to watch this movie in my french class as part of lets say "french culture". I thought the way it was filmed and the editing was real good but mostly it was entertaining especially the guy that played Wendy's brother. Also the story line was really good as well as it was believable and yet adventurous as well.Favorite Part: When William is making fun of the German guy studying and when he acts out how flies reproduce! :) My french isn't that good but with the subtitles i could pretty much get what was going on. WATCH IT!

Yes , this is one of the better done television movies and I would n't expect less from Joe Sargent , an accomplished director who is known for his skill in creating captivating content for the small screen. With its compelling storyline, engaging characters, and a brilliant execution, this movie serves as proof that TV films can also be on par with feature-length productions. Not to mention, Joe Sargent's fine attention to detail and the use of innovative storytelling techniques really sets the film apart. So if you're a fan of quality television, do not hesitate to check this film out.

This was the second Cinemascope spectacle that Fox produced after the Robe . Notice how some of the Roman sets were reused in this film, demonstrating the studio's resourcefulness in creating visually stunning productions while staying within budget constraints. This classic cinematic masterpiece was skillfully crafted and utilized state-of-the-art camera and sound technology of the time, making it one of the iconic examples of early widescreen cinema. A standout feature of the film is the engaging storytelling which combined action, drama, and historical themes seamlessly, appealing to audiences of various backgrounds.

After I 've seen this movie I find it hard to understand why so many people seem to hate this film. Yes, it may have its flaws and inconsistencies, but overall, I believe it offers an engaging story, strong performances, and an emotional connection with its audience. The visuals and sound design are immersive, pulling viewers into a thrilling, dramatic narrative. As a fan of cinema, I always appreciate films that leave me feeling entertained, reflective, or simply glad to have taken the time to experience a particular story.

I played Sam ( the porter , Lou 's sidekick ) in the Film `` Dead Rail '' Which later became a cult classic. Set in a dystopian world where Lou and Sam have to navigate through the post-apocalyptic terrain, their witty repartee quickly gained a fan following. Dead Rail gave a glimpse into humanity's darker side, with people grasping onto the remains of the collapsed society and surviving against all odds. As Lou's sidekick, Sam provided a blend of dark humor, charisma, and wit, solidifying our duo's reputation in the hearts of movie buffs.

"Two Hands" is an entertaining, funny story about Australian lowlifes. The screenplay contrasts the world of fast money and deadly acts with the inexplicability of fate and circumstance. In a subtle way we are asked to ponder the concept that major events in our lives are sometimes generated without our being fully aware of the root causes. The forces of fate and circumstance take Jimmy, the main character, into situations that bring about the realization of his shallow dreams and, ultimately, an understanding of a more personally promising world.The clueless Jimmy, portrayed with acumen by Heath Ledger, is a kid who grew up without opportunity.

Unlike some of the former commentators, I was (and am) an avid fan of the Carpenters. Face it, Christmas would never be Christmas without The Carpenters. That said, I believe the movie did a good, not excellent, job at depicting Karen's life. The movie was enjoyable to see on primetime TV, but the content fell a little short. I suggest that you all look into getting some of the Carpenters specials that were shown in the 70's. You cannot believe how awesome a drummer Karen was. Cynthia did not capture the extent of Karen's talent.

The Lone Ranger & Tonto set out to bring to justice a band of hooded raiders who have killed three Indians for what appears at first to be no apparent reason..that is until the Lone Ranger discovers from a conversation with the Indian Chief Tomache that each man possessed a medallion. The five medallions given by Tomache to his friends as gifts we later learn when combined will provide the mastermind behind the hooded raiders with a map to a legendary lost city of gold. Can the Lone Ranger protect the remaining two individuals in possession of the medallions before the hooded raiders get their hands on it?

Wow ! An amazing , lost piece of Australiana AND a lost 70s glam-rock film rolled into one . This gem from the past is like unearthing a treasure trove for nostalgia buffs and movie fanatics alike. Bursting with vibrant colors, a powerhouse of energetic performances and showcasing the Aussie sense of humor and raw spirit of the 70s, this astonishing blend of unforgettable Australiana and foot-stomping glam-rock hits the mark in every way. A heart-pounding flashback ride, this unique fusion sparks emotions of excitement and nostalgia, revitalizing an era of pulsating rhythms, glorious fashion, and poignant moments.

I thought I was wasting my precious 50 bucks going to watch this movie. But at the earnest request of my friend who is an ardent fan of Aparna Sen, I decided to turn up for the movie. Going at this cheap theater really bothered me, cos I had seen King Kong for 50 bucks at one of the best theatres in town. Anywasy the movie starts of and surprisingly I wasn't complaining. A great story and some really wonderful wonderful acting on Shabana Azmi and Konkona Sen Sharma's part. Shabana Azmi a divorc√©e who has dedicated her life to the well being of her mother and step sister.

I 'm a fan of independent film . Dialogue driven , character study pieces are where it 's at for me. There's something undeniably captivating about a movie that explores the human experience and psyche, unencumbered by big budget gimmicks or A-list celebrities. What independent films lack in production value, they make up for in depth and nuance. A truly memorable indie movie sinks its hooks into your soul, leaving you introspective, emotional, or provoked ‚Äì sometimes, all at once. More than just mindless entertainment, these artful narratives ignite thought and discussions about social and personal issues.

"Boy Next Door" is a hilarious romp through male neurosis. In just over fifteen minutes, the film takes us on a journey that most full-length features can't even match. Great performances, excellent camera work and editing---this short is a classic from start to finish. Kudos to Travis Davis for pulling double duty as both director and star. He's the funniest nebbish since Woody Allen. And what a treat to see Richard Moll back again. If you thought all he could do was play "Bull" the bailiff on "Night Court", think again.

Gilmore Girls is a hilarious show with never ending sarcasm , wit , and charm . At age 16 Lorelai Gilmore had a baby and named her Rory, who quickly became the center of her world. Set in the quirky town of Stars Hollow, Connecticut, the series focuses on the dynamic mother-daughter duo as they navigate life, love, and everything in between. Lorelai, now managing the Independence Inn, constantly juggles her complicated relationship with her parents, work challenges, and many quirky friends. Meanwhile, Rory experiences typical teenage struggles like academics, friendships, and romance ‚Äì all with her unique brand of humor and intelligence.

This twisted comedy is well acted and directed . Very funny and the production quality is outstanding . It is a refreshing change from the usual predictable comedy, incorporating a perfect balance of wit and sarcasm that keeps the audience on their toes. The eccentric characters are portrayed brilliantly, with each bringing their own unique quirks and complexities that add layers to the storyline. The smart dialogues and the creative direction contribute to its overall appeal. While exploring some dark and unexpected themes, the film cleverly navigates between humorous and dramatic moments. A truly memorable and distinctive experience worth watching for anyone craving originality and an excellent time.

I am a history teacher and overall I was pleased with the movie . My teen-agers enjoyed it over the weekend and found it to be engaging, as well as educational. The film managed to accurately depict the significant historical events while keeping the attention of younger viewers. The characters were well-developed, making it easier for the audience to understand their motives and the circumstances surrounding their actions. While the film may have taken some creative liberties, it sparked curiosity among my students to research further into the actual events, which in my opinion is an excellent outcome for any historical movie.

"Jaded" should not be considered as en erotic thriller because the sex scenes are not for viewing pleasure unlike movies like "Indecent Behavior" or "Friend Of The Family". "Jaded" is not an easy watch as it's story is difficult to conceive and it's not that common in society. From the beginning of the movie, with the first scene, you expect more strong scenes. The raping scene wasn't (in my opinion) a well created scene. I think that the director didn't use proper camera techniques overall in the movie.

The four signs on the road say "If You're Looking For Fun.....You Don't Need A Reason....All You Need Is A Gun....It's Rabbit Season! "In the woods, we see hundreds of "Rabbit Season" signs posted on every tree. We see more and more signs pointing exactly to Bugs Bunny's hole. Who's putting up all these signs? Daffy Duck!Daffy puts the last sign up, tiptoes away and says to us, the audience, "Awfully unsporting of me, I know.

15 PARK AVENUE is the address "Mithi/Mithali" (Konkona) is in search for from the movies beginning. "Prof.Anu" (Shabhana Azmi)is Mithi's extremely caring and loving half sister from Mithi's mom's earlier marriage. The movie revolves around these characters and looks into the life of a schizophrenic patient (Mithi). The director tries to explain to the viewer the imaginary world of Mithi, through her continuous blabbering to Anu and others. Konkona deserves not one but thousands of awards (which I am sure, she will be getting)for this rendition of Mithi in this movie.

I saw "The Reader" at a film festival in Manhattan this week. It touched my heart in a way that few short films have done. In ten or so minutes, it tells a poignant two-character story that resonated deeply with me. Duncan Rogers has done a superb job capturing very real, tender moments on film. What I really admire about this film is that the director has chosen a story appropriate to the short format. These are genuinely interesting characters, and their story is told in the perfect length of time. This is no small feat.

A classic late 50's film. The superannuated headliners (Joan Crawford and Louis Jordan) are not at their best, but the direction, cinematography, and acting of the younger cast are compelling. In a 50's sense (which I love).The look and feel of the artsy (over-artsy?) contemporary film "Far from heaven" reflects exactly this sort of film (and I suspect this film may be one of the models). A silly plot, of course (hey, it's 1959! ), but as a film-- glorious!

I first saw this movie on TV back in 1959 when I was eight years old . I knew nothing about cinema or actors at that time, but the enchanting storytelling and the vivid colors captivated my young mind. The vibrant characters played by actors unknown to me felt like a thrilling adventure beyond my usual mundane life. Watching this film felt like I had opened a doorway to an incredible new world of cinematic fantasy. Little did I know then that this experience would not only shape my love for movies but also inspire me to be more imaginative in life.

I couldn't believe the eye candy from start to finish. Being a fan of movies directed by music video masterminds. I am happy to report that the photography in this motion picture is a splendor for the eye to behold. There are so many rich, full images that are put before me, that each and every time that I see this movie, I find something new that I had not seen before. As with previous movies that I have seen, such as Blade and Mystery Men, also by former music video directors, the use of color to capture one's attention is utilized extremely well.

Having grown up in the typing pool era and dealing with office politics and men who were apt to make a banquet of beauties into a delightful meal day to day, this movie hits the mark. Good afternoon fare. I understand that Louis Jordan wanted to work in this movie to play opposite the quintessential GORGEOUS Suzy Parker. Everyone wanted to be in and I believe it has done well and held up over time. Best on screen kiss between Hope Lange and the late Stephen Boyd.It may not appear that anything of this is plausible but actually it was and probably still is even given the scare of sexual harassment.

A good old-fashioned flight-and-revenge western, given a twist and a touch of gravitas by injecting a little black social history into its plot. Lead by Mario Van Peebles, who does OK, the gang of misfits on the run from Billy Zane's (seemingly unstoppable) army bigwig all acquit themselves well, their adventures plausible yet fun and exciting. There're some nice moody flashback scenes setting up the hero's character and backstory, a good shoot-out ending as our heroes defend the town from greedy white landgrabbers, and even Stephen Baldwin isn't bad in this enjoyable, quite powerful western.

This small John Ford western with no 'stars ' but a cast of character actors is one of his masterpieces . "3 Godfathers" (1948) boasts a unique story that conveys genuine emotions through raw human connections rather than gunfights and chases. The premise follows three outlaws who become surrogate fathers to an abandoned baby, forcing them to navigate both physical and emotional deserts on a redemptive path. Poignant in its execution and dripping with themes of camaraderie, sacrifice, and redemption, Ford deftly weaves heartbreak with comic relief through unforgettable performances from his lesser-known cast.

One of the best! As being a fan of the civil war, I was very pleased with the first installment of the North and South trilogy. Patrick Swayze gives and extraordinary performance, as well as James Reed and Leslie Ann Down. In watching this fabulous story unfold into a time never forgotten, the subjects of love, passion, grief, shame, harmony, and cruelty come to life. I was first introduced to this series when I was in the eighth grade. Being a young boy, you would think that I wouldn't have been interested in this civil war soap.

What can I say? You expect only the best in drama from the BBC and MESSIAH is not an exception to the rule.MESSIAH is a great thriller, a truly shocking and creepy tale about a serial killer who cuts out victims' tongues and replaces them with silver spoons. Police Officer Red Metcalfe (Ken Stott) and his team have the task of trying to solve the mystery of the seemingly random events, before more lives are lost.But be warned - despite it's '15' rating (in the UK), MESSIAH is a bit of a gruesome film.

Obsessed ! ! ! ! ! I have every season of Gilmore Girls and I think the reason I love it so much is because it brings such a sense of nostalgia, warmth, and relatability. The witty and fast-paced dialogue between Lorelai and Rory, combined with the idyllic setting of Stars Hollow, truly make this show a feel-good masterpiece. As a young woman, I deeply connect with the issues the characters face: love, loss, ambition, family and friendships. Every character brings a unique charm, which makes it nearly impossible to have a favorite.

I just want to say that Chris Diamantopoulos 's role as Williams for that entire show , was Emmy worthy I cannot emphasize enough the remarkable portrayal of Williams by Chris Diamantopoulos throughout the show. The depth he brought to his character's personality truly transcended the expectations for the series. The emotional nuances, along with the perfectly timed mannerisms, truly highlight the incredible range of Diamantopoulos as an actor. The captivating screen presence combined with an incredibly immersive performance deserved recognition in the form of an Emmy award. It is astonishing and disheartening to see that his phenomenal acting did not receive the credit it clearly merited.

I haven't seen a film in a long time that moved me and gripped me in such a way; that I couldn't take my eyes off the screen. I was busting for the loo; and I didn't even want to pause it because I was drawn right in. Emotive; powerful; very moving; horrific and heart-breaking. It gives you an amazing insight to South Africa; their struggles and their lives. The acting by the leads were mind-blowing and the script was incredible. Despite the terrible events that unfold in this film and how horrific the story is; I was captivated.

The first thing I wanted to do after watching this film was watch it again (because I'd missed lots with all the laughing I did). I'm European and I've studied abroad and I've as good as lived with Spanish, french, Italian and German people. The film was full of stereotypes, which, more often than not, p*** people off, and reading some of the other reviews I see that it did p*** people off. But, this film gets the stereotypes so right I cannot fault it.

Finally a true horror movie. This is the first time in years that I had to cover my eyes. I am a horror buff and I recommend this movie but it is quite gory. I am not a big wrestling fan but Kane really pulled the whole monster thing off. I have to admit that I didn't want to see this movie, my 17 year old dragged me to it, but am very glad I did. During and after the movie I was looking over my shoulder. I have to agree with others about the whole remake horror movies enough is enough.

I saw Riverdance - The New Show and loved it from the very first moment ! It is an energetic and mesmerizing performance that combines the beauty of traditional Irish music and dance with contemporary flair. The ensemble showcases astounding precision, timing, and synchrony, taking my breath away as they grace the stage with powerful yet elegant movements. Live musicians only add to the palpable energy, capturing the essence of Irish culture through the lively tunes. Remarkable solo performances effortlessly merge with ensemble pieces, creating a rich visual tapestry that left me entranced.

I lack cable-vision and no longer have "DirecTV". So being a rural resident I have to wait for DVD releases. Being a lover of blondes but not blonds, I of course not only have "Barb Wire", but I have "Stripperella: The Complete First Season". I've not yet found "VIP" or a second season for Stripperella. I have the "Baywatch Hawaiian Wedding" DVD. I have the issues of "Playboy" that Pamela Denise Anderson posed in. I could go on. I love Pamela!

I just saw this wonderfully filmed movie that captures the essence ofhigh-brow NYC , or any big city of mid-century America. Set against the vibrant backdrop of mid-20th century Manhattan, the film brilliantly showcases the city's rich cultural history and exudes a genuine vintage atmosphere. From bustling jazz clubs and high-end fashion boutiques, to classic cocktail bars and eclectic street performers, it vividly captures the essence of the sophisticated, diverse urban landscape during this transformative period. A unique glimpse into a bygone era, this movie takes the audience on an immersive visual journey, painting an alluring portrait of high-brow New York City life during its cultural heyday.

I 'd honestly give this movie a solid 7.5 , but I clicked 10 to try to offset the 5 .8 average rating. While not a perfect film, it undoubtedly deserves better recognition than what it's been given. This movie managed to strike a chord with its fascinating storyline and engaging characters. Despite some pacing issues and predictable moments, the film succeeded in capturing the viewer's attention and leaving a lasting impression. It could have benefitted from better direction, but the unique concept alone is enough for people to appreciate the creativity put into the film.

It has been recorded that John Ford made the `` big , blockbuster '' movies so that he could afford to create his more artistic and personally meaningful projects. Ford's desire for artistic integrity led him to master the fine balance between commercial success and creative vision, often delivering outstanding movies that won awards and generated significant revenue. His innovative film-making techniques, combined with rich storytelling and captivating character development, elevated the entire industry's expectations of what a movie could and should be. He simultaneously forged his own distinct visual and thematic styles and secured himself as one of the pioneering legends of cinematic history.

I just watched this movie on it 's premier night out of curiosity and sheer nostalgia . I liked ( the original version and was interested to see how they had adapted it for a modern audience. To my surprise and delight, the filmmakers managed to maintain the charm and essence of the original while infusing it with contemporary themes and technology. The actors truly embodied the characters, with performances that brought a sense of depth and humanity. Visually, the cinematography was stunning, showcasing the vivid landscapes that gave life to the story.

Excellent entry in the RKO Saint series with well-written original script , good camera work and transitions , good directing and outstanding performances from the cast. The intricate storyline keeps the viewers engaged while showcasing creative ingenuity in developing character arcs. Cinematography captures the essence of the film, allowing the audience to immerse themselves in its atmosphere. The use of innovative techniques during pivotal scenes leaves a memorable impact. Kudos to the talented director for his vision and skillful execution. Overall, this RKO Saint installment triumphs in providing viewers with a high-quality production, captivating experience, and a thought-provoking film that transcends its era.

I saw this movie with my girlfriends and we all loved it! It is so sweet and heartwarming, a real tear-jerker! I was still thinking about the story days after i'd seen the movie. It's such a beautiful story about the difficult things all families go through, it's something anybody can relate to. I really recommend this movie to anybody looking for a Saturday night rental. With your girlfriends, your family, your boyfriend, everyone will really enjoy it! :D It's a real story about a real family that would pull at anyones heartstrings.

I think the problem with this show not getting the respect it truly deserves is that it comes after Seinfeld,after ELR and after Friends. Those three sitcoms were the star shows of their time.KOQs came at the end of this special time in TV. But don't let that dissuade you.King of Queens is as good if not better than two of the three mentioned.Seinfeld started it all and was and is a timeless classic. I never laughed so hard than I did at Seinfeld. But KOQs comes real close.When it comes to laughing, I have to rate KOQs second only to Seinfeld.

what was the quote by archbishop tutu at the end of the film about a person's past? this film was very disturbing to watch in the sense that it was a true story and to think that humanity is still so cruel after all these years makes me ashamed everyone is human and everyone has the right to live their life in peace and harmony live and let liveif anyone knows the quote please let me know Thank youthis film should be shown a lot more publicly as true events as horrific as these shown in the film should be known to all in the hope that things will change sooner rather than later.

Wagon Master is a very unique film amongst John Ford 's work . Mainly because it 's the only one in his impressive repertoire that centers around a group of Mormon pioneers searching for their promised land. Released in 1950, this Western film offers a different perspective, moving away from the conventional lone cowboy narrative to depict the struggles of a whole community on a wagon trail, as they strive for peace, love, and tolerance in the face of numerous obstacles. Noted for its stark cinematography and extraordinary ensemble performances, Wagon Master showcases the director's commitment to powerful human stories.

The most beautiful film. If one is looking for serious depth, meaning and excellent performance then you have to get to watch this movie. excellent performances by the whole cast. Even more beautiful than A Beautiful Mind itself. Simply awesome!! I wish this movie entered the Oscars. I cried through the whole movie for the schizophrenic character. ..The most beautiful film. If one is looking for serious depth, meaning and excellent performance then you have to get to watch this movie. excellent performances by the whole cast. Even more beautiful than A Beautiful Mind itself.

One of the genres that flourished during the decade of the 30s was the variation of crime fiction known as "hardboiled" detective fiction. Pioneered by the likes of Dashiell Hammett and Raymond Chandler, these stories focused on the cynical, world-weary private investigators as they navigated through seedy urban environments filled with corruption, deceit, and violence. Rather than neat puzzle-like whodunits, hardboiled fiction delved into social realism and moral ambiguity, creating a more gripping portrayal of crime and those who fought against it. With gritty prose and morally ambiguous antiheroes, the 1930s crime fiction had a major impact on shaping modern detective and mystery fiction.

This movie was so cool! I saw it on a Friday night with a couple of my friends. While the first credits were rolling, we saw that Lionsgate Films had made this movie. They are the ones that made that stupid movie Wolf Creek, which was totally gay! When we saw this, we groaned. We thought it was going to be like Wolf Creek, but we were so wrong! The movie was not only better than Wolf Creek (which really isn't that hard) it is one of the best horror movies I have seen in a long time!

Hmm , is it right to compare Tiffani Thiessen and Mark-Paul Gosselaar 's post Saved By The Bell acting ? Both Tiffani Thiessen and Mark-Paul Gosselaar have indeed had successful careers after Saved by the Bell; however, it is a subjective question to ask if comparing their post-show acting careers is justifiable or fair. Every actor takes different paths, plays diverse roles, and builds their own legacy. Tiffani has achieved remarkable recognition in shows like Beverly Hills, 90210 and White Collar, while Mark-Paul has successfully landed main roles in series like NYPD Blue and Franklin & Bash.

I'm not the type of person to watch T.V. shows because the acting normally sucks or it's unrealistic or TOO dramatic! But this show is perfect. Everyone can act, and you can relate to the characters and their situations. Everyone has their own personality and Lorelai Gilmore is the best for her sarcastic comments that can make any bad situation seem a little funny. Rory Gilmore is a good role model for all girls. She takes pride in wanting to attend Harvard and boys/boyfriends always come second in her book. She's a loyal friend and always the peace maker.

Having read all of the comments on this film I am still amazed at Fox's reluctance to release a full screen restored version in DVD. Yes, the history may be a bit inaccurate and it is certainly not as powerful as the book, BUT it was the 2nd film by Fox made in Real Cinemascope and the production values alone merit a restoration and distribution. I saw this film in second grade and it triggered my lifelong interest in all things Egyptian, culminating in my visiting Egypt 4 years ago! Amazing the power of film on a child's imagination, eh?

It may have been inevitable that with the onslaught of "slasher" movies in the early 1980's, that a few good ones might slip through the cracks. This is a great "rare" film from Jeff Lieberman, who insured his cult status with his memorable 1970's films "Squirm" and "Blue Sunshine".Five young people head into the Oregon mountains (this movie was actually shot on location) to do some camping and check out the deed to some land that one of them has acquired. Before long, they will predictably be terrorized by a bulky killer with an incredibly creepy wheezing laugh.

honestly .. this show warms my heart , i watch it EVERYDAY on fox family and now that the new episodes are airing, I am just thrilled. The storyline and characters never cease to make me laugh and cheer me up when I'm down. It's not just the comedy though, it's also the heartfelt moments that genuinely touch my emotions. I feel as if I am growing alongside the characters, and they become a sort of extended family to me. It is truly rare to find a TV show with such heart, depth and realness.

does anyone know where i could get my hands on this video or the film for this . I have been searching for it everywhere, but it seems nearly impossible to find. I've already tried looking through popular platforms like YouTube, Netflix, and Amazon Prime, as well as scouring torrent websites, but all of my efforts have proved fruitless. If anyone could direct me to a local rental store or online streaming website where I can finally get a copy of this video or film, it would be greatly appreciated!

I not only consider this to be the best film that Jon Voight (Midnight Cowboy, Coming Home) has ever done, but a real tribute to teachers.Despite incredible odds, Pat Conroy (Voight) managed to reach a group of students and bring them from nowhere to a basic literacy and awareness of the world. His methods made be criticized by bureaucratic dinosaurs like Mr. Skeffington (Hume Cronyn), but teachers like Conroy will always be winners.Voight really showed that he had a love for teaching and that it was a natural high for him.

George Cukor is and always will be one of my favorites. The unsung hero of his generation. Nobody mentions Cukor in the same breath as John Ford, Howard Hawks, William Wyler or Billy Wilder and yet, look at his filmography. From sparkling comedies "The Philadelphia Story" "Adam's Rib" "Holiday" Psycho melodramas "Gaslight" "A Double Life" a great semi western "Heller in Pink Tights" not to mention "My Fair Lady" or "Travels with my Aunt" He was at the service of his actors, he never put himself in front of the camera.

Blue Planet... Wow... Where do I begin? The years of hard work paid off in what is, without question, one of the best documentaries ever created.The sights and sounds presented in Blue Planet, like most documentaries with the Attenborough stamp, are rare and haven't even experienced by most people. That alone should be enough reason to buy this series, especially if you're the curious type who 'wants to know'.Blue Planet is not a perfect documentary, however. It does get a bit repetitive after the 3rd episode.

Robin Hood : Men in Tights ( 1993 ) was a much needed parody from Mel Brooks . He has successfully reimagined the classic Robin Hood legend in a comedic and lighthearted way. Starring Cary Elwes as the charismatic and charming Robin Hood, the film lampoons the cliches and stereotypes prevalent in earlier adaptations of the timeless story. Complete with catchy musical numbers and a witty script filled with double entendres, Men in Tights brilliantly blends slapstick and verbal humor, satisfying both new and seasoned fans of Robin Hood. Mel Brooks proves, once again, his mastery in satire, making this movie an unforgettable addition to his exceptional body of work.

Very good "Precoder" starring Dick Barthelmess, which in a way, kind of reminded me of Hawks' "Only Angels Have Wings" (1939), in which Barthelmess also acted. This film was directed by masterful William Wellman, who was responsible for the landmark aviation Silent picture "Wings".Barthelmess plays a devil-may-care airplane pilot, who is a blamed for an aviation accident. Afterwards he meets and falls for pretty Sally Eilers, who participates as part of an Act in an itinerant Air Circus; but when Barthelmess' brother appears in scene, a triangular relationship ensues.

Two horse traders arrive in a town and meet up with the leader of a group of Mormons who are settling there. The traders, experienced in striking deals, are keen to profit from the Mormons' needs. The Mormon leader, aware of the challenges in building their settlement, is cautious but hopeful about the prospects the traders offer. The two parties engage in spirited negotiations, forging an agreement that seems fair for both. In the days to come, the traders provide horses and services vital for the growth and progress of the settlement.

One of the biggest French success of the year 2002, "l'auberge espagnole" was also very well greeted abroad which is quite extraordinary for a French film. It is not difficult to define the reasons of this success. This movie made by one of the most interesting French film-makers of these last years, C√©dric Klapisch, presents students coming from all over Europe and gathered all together under the same roof in Barcelona. These students are described like the ones you imagine or you see in everyday life: either untidy, either serious or with a sense of humor.

Cant believe it.... after all these years finally tracked this down.. it was meant to be named 'The Great Pretender' at production stage. I was living in Oz at time and through a friend was looking after one of the house locations through filming.... It was me that showed these guys how to speak Scottish and after all this time, I only realise now one was Russell Crowe !!! It has taken me all these years to track this down, was even unsure if it ever went to screen as I left Oz the following month after wrap up party.

Watching this film caused quite an emotional reaction . This is what today 's documentaries are all about . It explores complex social and psychological themes while captivating the audience with powerful storytelling. The director skillfully combines elements of drama and intrigue with a sensitivity towards real human issues. Today's documentaries challenge conventional beliefs, encourage us to ask difficult questions, and prompt self-reflection. With their artistic cinematography, honest narratives, and impeccable research, these films can be life-changing experiences. They evoke powerful emotions, engage the audience in thought-provoking conversations, and remind us of our shared humanity in this diverse and ever-changing world.

Craig Brewer is now officially a writer/director for whom I will see any film by , no matter how bad it might seem on the surface. After his captivating work on "Hustle & Flow" and "Black Snake Moan", Brewer has proven to possess a unique storytelling ability and a strong grasp of complex, dynamic characters. Even if the premise of his upcoming project appears questionable, I have faith that Brewer's unparalleled directorial prowess and screenwriting talent will successfully bring a seemingly poor concept to life with skill and emotional resonance. Hence, his filmography demands further exploration and attention, earning him a loyal follower in me.

Not knowing a great deal about the Truth and Reconciliation commission, I can only look at this as a piece of entertainment. I started watching it too late in the evening (recorded from BBC2 earlier this year) but once I'd started I had to watch to the end.The down-side is that it's effectively a courtroom drama - never my favourite genre - but it's stunningly photographed (largely in super-saturated ochres) and well acted. Like a good novel, I couldn't put it down. All the way through, I wished I was watching it in a cinema to do the music and photography justice.

I went straight to the big screen to view this kicker. This is the only flick that I know of that Tarsem Singh has directed but boy was it intense. This movie was a total mind stimulant and one of the best special effects flick of this kind.The characters were vibrant and and nothing short of beings created in your own mind or nightmare. This movie is scary and interesting and totally bombs the senses with fear and exhilaration. This movie compares to no other I have seen except for the level of being beautifully odd. In that respect it is a fairly large step above `A Clockwork Orange.'

This 1959 soap opera film takes us into the lives and loves of three young women in the publishing world as secretaries. This follows the same idea as THREE COINS IN A FOUNTAIN a few years before. This takes place in New York while COINS takes place in Rome, Italy. Our three beauties are Hope Lange, in her first starring role, Suzy Parker and Diane Baker. Lange does well and holds her own opposite some strong veterans in the business, namely Joan Crawford. Suzy plays an obsessive woman who has a hard time losing her beau.

Nurse Betty has that odd but winning combination of a repellent, unease-inducing plot with extraordinary characters. In the same way I loathed Fargo on first viewing, then realized I was still thinking about it days later and enjoying it somehow, I liked Nurse Betty a lot more the day after I saw it. Hard to understand, harder to explain. As others have said, it's quite forced in many ways, but that seems to be part of what makes it so striking.Fair job by Greg Kinnear, great work from Morgan Freeman (although I worry that he's being stereotyped as the principled villain).

Sweeping drama with great sets , costumes and performances ¬ñ though some folks are channeling Rhett , Scarlett , Melanie , and Ashley from the classic Gone with the Wind, this new cinematic spectacle has its own distinctive flair. Fusing themes of passion, heartache, and betrayal against the grandeur of the backdrop, the gripping narrative is infused with a modern perspective. Enthralling cinematography accompanies beautifully curated sets, making every scene an artistic gem. Coupled with superb acting from an exquisite ensemble cast that does more than echo their famed predecessors, audiences are treated to an emotionally immersive and visually-stunning period drama experience that stands on its own merits.

POSSIBLE SPOILERSNo one is likely to pick up a DVD of Red Dust without knowing that it is about South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission. Hilary Swank stars as a South African exile who returns to her home town as a lawyer representing Alex Mpondo (Chiwetel Ejiofer), a member of the South African parliament who was tortured by a prison guard, Pete Muller (Ian Roberts), who is seeking to escape prison by testifying before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. They could certainly have found an actress who has or could imitate a South African accent; Ms. Swank makes no attempt whatsoever to cover her unmistakably American accent.

I own the miniseries on DVD because I love this story so much. This is one of the best period pieces on the Civil War that I have seen that tells a story of friendship divided by the war. The costumes are great, the story lines are great, I love how the story jumps around from character to character to keep you guessing as to what's going to happen next in their lives. There is a great balance of good and evil. Some of the characters that are evil in my opinion are too good not to watch.

This show is really great . It 's smart.It 's funny.It 's great acting and writing . This show is truly a gem in the vast sea of TV shows out there today. The plot is captivating, filled with unexpected twists and turns that constantly keep the audience guessing. The humor is intelligent, sharp and perfectly executed by a stellar ensemble cast that brings their characters to life. The writing, both in dialogue and storyline development, never falters or falls short of the high bar it sets for itself. Viewers who dive into this masterpiece are met with laughter, emotions, and thrills.

SPOILERS AHEAD -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- - Mel has got it going on with a major reveal that is bound to shock everyone. Despite previous assumptions and misleading hints, it turns out that the protagonist is in fact Mel's estranged twin brother. In a twisted series of events, their lives become dangerously entangled as family secrets come to light. Characters you believed to be innocent reveal darker intentions, forcing Mel to confront these newfound betrayals. Tensions rise as hidden motives emerge, shattering relationships and exposing lies in this unexpected, thrilling twist of a narrative.

A question immediately arises in this extremely idiosyncratic film : Who are the crazy people ? The answer become less and less clear as the plot unfolds, leaving viewers bewildered yet fascinated by this quirky masterpiece. Both the characters and the storyline dance on a fine line between sanity and insanity, as viewers find themselves constantly re-evaluating their initial judgments. With moments of dark humor and heartbreaking vulnerability, the film dives deep into the complexities of the human psyche, ultimately proving that perhaps all of us have a touch of madness within us.

Being an avid Carpenter Fan , I really loved this film ( although the wigs do leave a lot to be desired). It's a brilliant homage to his classic style, complete with spine-chilling music and heart-racing suspense. The combination of action and horror creates an electrifying atmosphere that keeps you on the edge of your seat, while the characters remain compelling throughout the story. What makes this movie even more special are the nods to some of Carpenter's greatest works. So, for fans who relish in all things 80's and Carpenter-esque, this film is definitely a must-watch.

I'll be brief: I normally hate films like this venomously ... but there is just something about this one that just draws me in and won't let me go. Granted, there are some major flaws in it (some of the acting is below par at best and the dialogue is sometimes so poor it's funny) but there are enough redeeming features to make it watchable to the end.But what are they? Well, it's got a cool little plot - by no means is it original, but it is better presented than other films of its kind.

I would probably not have bothered to comment on this film if I had not been disturbed by the constant stream of negative reviews it has received. It seems that viewers went in expecting a life-changing masterpiece, only to be disappointed. But in reality, this film doesn't aspire to change your life, it aims to entertain and it certainly achieves that goal. Despite its predictable storyline and cliched characterizations, this film remains enjoyable and visually captivating. The talented cast and top-notch production values offer a level of escapism that many could benefit from, especially in today's turbulent times.

Im a die hard Dads Army fan and nothing will ever change that. I got all the tapes, DVD's and audiobooks and every time i watch/listen to them its brand new. The film. The film is a re run of certain episodes, Man and the hour, Enemy within the gates, Battle School and numerous others with a different edge. Introduction of a new General instead of Captain Square was a brilliant move - especially when he wouldn't cash the cheque (something that is rarely done now).It follows through the early years of getting equipment and uniforms, starting up and training.

This movie is Wonderful ! I can watch it again and again . Robin hood is Perfectly cast , and the chemistry between him and Marian is simply enchanting. The supporting characters, such as Friar Tuck and Little John, add a perfect mix of comedy and drama, making the whole story even more captivating. The vivid cinematography transports the audience to the Sherwood Forest, and the period-authentic costumes and set design immerse us into the world of medieval England. Additionally, the thrilling action scenes and dramatic musical score will keep you at the edge of your seat throughout the film.

I loved this movie ! OH MY GOSH ! This movie rocked so hard ! I found it amongst some old DVDs at a garage sale, and boy, am I glad I picked it up! The storyline was incredibly captivating and the acting was top-notch. The soundtrack just added to the amazing vibe the film brought. Even though the visuals and special effects were clearly a bit dated, they still had a nostalgic charm to them. I would highly recommend giving this hidden gem a watch if you're in the mood for a fantastic throwback film. You won't be disappointed!

Susie Q. is one of those rare, and sweet movies that give you a warm feeling. It's bittersweet, but wholesome, and it's characters are fun, and captivating. At first, I thought the movie would be the clich√© cuddly movie that would bore me after five minutes, but was I wrong. It made me tear up at times, and it's plot was enticing, making me root for the good guys. I loved the movie, and still remember it today, 9 years later!!

The most enjoyable pet movie since Scooby Doo and Garfield. The story revolves around a 23 year old inventor named Brian Foster whose systems at his boss's company seems to keep failing, Brian is also dating the boss's daughter named Casey. But Brian secretly invented a robotic dog named CHOMPS, modeled after his own dog Rascal. But CHOMPS is no ordinarily dog, he is as fast as a cheetah, he has x-ray vision, can leap about 6 feet, and has a strength of 20 men. The new invention impresses his boss, and makes his business a success.

Having reviewed 3 of the 4 Perry and Croft sitcoms , I thought I would get them all done now by watching the last remaining series. Though the final Perry and Croft creation isn't as well-known as their other masterpieces like "Dad's Army," "Are You Being Served?" and "It Ain't Half Hot Mum," it still brings in the nostalgic vibes from the duo's classic writing. Upon starting the fourth installment, I noticed their undeniable talent of creating memorable characters and skillfully weaving lighthearted comedy through an ensemble of unique personalities.

'The Cell ' is a journey into the mind of a serial killer and I mean this literally . The movie transports viewers into the twisted and disturbed consciousness of the murderer, pushing the boundaries of reality and delving deep into the horrifying fantasies that drive their actions. Filled with dark, surreal, and shocking imagery, the film masterfully interweaves suspense and terror to keep viewers on the edge of their seats. The audience becomes both detective and psychologist, navigating through layers of brutality and discovering disturbing insights into the true nature of evil.

This is definitely one of the better Mel Brooks movies, along with Spaceballs(although I will openly admit to not having watched many others, at least yet). It's very silly and thoroughly funny, there are hardly more than a few minutes throughout the entire two hour run-time, where you aren't entertained. Almost all of the gags have a great comical effect, few of them fall flat. I saw this movie right after seeing and reviewing Spy Hard, and comparing these two spoof movies, I realize exactly of how high quality this movie really is.

Almost four years after the Iraq war started and we're in a bigger hole than ever. That's right, so all those flag wavers who were so sure of the right and might of the American way are now chasing their tails, isn't that true? You bet it is. This movie said so from the beginning. It is kind of freaky how much the film,or should I say, filmmaker, knew what was coming. It is almost like going to a fortune teller and hearing what was going to happen in the future.

Eager electronics whiz Brian Foster (a likable performance by Wesley Eure of TV's "Land of the Lost") creates a computerized watchdog called C.H.O.M.P.S. (an acronym for Canine Home Protection System) for his boss Mr. Ralph Norton (nicely played by Conrad Baain), whose home security business is floundering. A rival company hires a pair of inept criminals to get their grubby hands on C.H.O.M.P.S. ; said task proves to be easier said than done. Director Don Chaffey relates the endearingly dopey story at a constant brisk pace, maintains an amiably silly and lighthearted tone throughout, and stages the goofy slapstick gags with considerable flair.

North and South is a miniseries from the `` golden age '' of television miniseries in the 1980s , which chronicles the story of two families ‚Äì the Hazards, from the North, and the Mains, from the South ‚Äì against the backdrop of the Civil War. Featuring an ensemble cast, it effectively portrays the friendship, love, rivalry, and enmity between the families, their ties deepening amidst personal and societal upheavals. As the Civil War rages, both sides face monumental tragedies, family betrayals, and social clashes. As old wounds resurface, newfound alliances emerge.

I couldn't believe that the Adult Swim guys came up with this character. I laughed for days just thinking about this show. Having finally seen the pilot I guess I will stick around for a few more episodes. Assy is pretty funny and the whole crew of police show characters are around, but Assy is hard to understand and that was a little frustrating. Most of the humor revolves around the fact that the title character is literally a walking ass with nothing else but legs that sport socks with garters and feet with traditional wing tips.

there 's only so much that i can take of Filipino films , especially nowadays where the trend is sex ual innuendos, unoriginal storylines, and cookie-cutter love teams. To find gems among the current selection of films can prove to be a struggle. One cannot blame the viewers who opt for international or independent movies which showcase the kind of originality and depth in content, a stark contrast to mainstream Filipino offerings. What once were memorable and powerful themes from directors like Lino Brocka or Ishmael Bernal now mostly rely on provocative concepts to lure the audiences in, with the actual value of the storyline sometimes forgotten.

I caught this as part of the Cartoon Noir package at the Clinton Street Theater in Portland , and it was an unforgettable experience. The whole event showcased a variety of animated masterpieces in a moody, mysterious style, typical of the Noir genre. At the Clinton Street Theater, the dimly lit setting and old-time vibe complemented the essence of Cartoon Noir. Each short film focused on gritty themes, sharp dialogue, and exaggerated, heavy shadows, leaving the audience intrigued and absorbed in every moment. Witnessing these dark tales unravel at such an intimate venue took the viewers on a riveting journey back to the heyday of classic film noir.

This movie used to be played constantly on the Disney Channel when I was a bit younger, and I really remember liking it. However, I didn't have great taste back then (not to say that I do now) so I can't vouch for my nine-year-old self too well. The movie was probably a 7/10 but it had some good music so I gave it an extra point. Yeah, worth watching. I know that some fans of this movie are wondering what a certain song is - the one that appears when she is in the car crash.

I only gave this nine stars instead of ten because i really don't approve of pornography all that much. pornography has a useful purpose in society(can't say i can always think of one)but it probably does.personal viewpoints set aside, i really thought this film was pretty funny. i didn't buy this movie because it was pornography, i bought it because i am one of those 'Alice' obsessives who will watch anything about 'Alice in Wonderland'. i own just about every version there is on DVD so it was an obvious choice to complete my DVD collection with this.

I like movies that show real people `` Americans '' and tell truth . The movie is simple and that 's what makes it captivating. It sheds light on the daily lives and struggles of ordinary Americans, presenting an honest reflection of their world. This honesty makes the characters relatable and easy to sympathize with, while the grounded storytelling approach ensures there's no sugarcoating. One of my favorites is an indie film that perfectly illustrates this - capturing raw emotions, inner conflicts, and hopes for a better life. It tackles relevant social issues and embraces both humor and heartbreak.

A lot about USA The Movie can be summed up in its title. It draws parallels between the attitudes of this country in the face of war and a kind of Hollywood-like falseness that glorifies things that shouldn't be glorified. I'm not sure I agree with the filmmaker's take on recent events (although, truthfully, I can't always tell exactly where he stands) but I admire the unusual and artistic way of getting the point across. Audio tracks of speeches, radio interviews, poetry etc. play as large a role here as visuals.

I have to say that this film was excellently produced and tops the ratings as a typical sci fi film! I enjoyed it.. its a sci fi film, if you want a thriller watch another channel.. This is what the scifi lovers want. Excellently produced by one of Sci-fi's best producers Scot Vandiver ! OK the special effects weren't excellent, but what a great cast! Some more money could have been used for effects but then again what sci fi has high budgeted effects. Stop complaining and change the channel if you don't like these type of films..

Sweeping drama with great sets, costumes and performances ¬ñ though some folks are channeling Rhett, Scarlett, Melanie and even Lady Macbeth. Patrick Swayze and James Read are excellent as two men trying to maintain a friendship despite the ties of family and location. Splendid villains ¬ñ you'll want them all to come to a very bad end. Lots of strong female characters in this one ¬ñ both good and bad. Secondary story lines also are well developed. Several cameos by major stars of past eras. Good representation of history and conflicts for those caught between friendship and politics.

This film predates the Australian films Road Warrior and Priscilla of the Desert, and its influence on them is obvious: in the dialogue, locations, photography, direction and political philosophy. The photography is notably confident. The direction is stylish and for the most part well done. If you liked the early Australian films by Bruce Beresford, Peter Weir and George Miller then you'll love "Oz". The direction also reminds this reviewer of Edgar Wright's contemporary work. That similarity suggests that "Oz" was far ahead of its time.

George Cuckor , known as a director of women , could n't have hoped for two more talented and beautiful actresses than Katharine Hepburn and Audrey Hepburn, no relation, to showcase in his films. Working with Katharine in classics like "The Philadelphia Story" (1940) and "Little Women" (1933), Cukor knew how to bring out the best in her strong-willed yet endearing characters. He showcased Audrey's charisma in his adaptation of the famous play "My Fair Lady" (1964), molding her into the perfect embodiment of the graceful and intelligent Eliza Doolittle.

The above summary really isn't meant as a slam against this film, as the series followed a very similar format. As usual, Simon Templar ("The Saint") meets a lady in distress and comes to her aid. He also comes to the aid of a police detective who was framed of accepting a bribe. Along the way, he meets some interesting supporting characters (this time, Paul Guilfoyle as "Pearly" Gates) and during his unraveling of this not especially compelling mystery (none of them really are), Templar is extremely erudite and just plain cool!

This as the first of the Ma and Pa Kettle flicks . Marjorie Main ( Ma ) steals the show as the no-nonsense yet kind-hearted mother figure, and Percy Kilbride (Pa) provides the perfect comic relief as the laid-back, loveable father. Together, they tackle life in their rural farm community, dealing with their eccentric children, meddling neighbors, and endless shenanigans. Audiences loved watching the crazy antics unfold and couldn't help but root for this offbeat family, as they overcame obstacles and tried to fit into the ever-changing society around them.

Brilliant film ! I am sorry to say that it resembles to me a bit like Pulp F. but thats only a small detail. The storyline is gripping, the characters are incredibly well-developed, and the cinematography is truly stunning. Yes, there are similarities with Pulp Fiction, but it stands on its own as a fresh and unique experience. The twists and turns in the plot leave you guessing until the very end, making it impossible to predict the outcome. The perfect blend of drama, suspense, and humor provides a balanced and captivating experience.

I have watched this show from the beginning, and I am a 45 year old man. To me, this is so much more that a show that appeals to women. This is the story of a family, possibly an unusual one, but a family none the less. It centers around a mother and daughter, Lorelei and Rory Gilmore, two bright, attractive, and in their own ways successful women. Lorelei makes her home in fictional Stars Hollow, CT, a small New England town with a sense of history, and a population of people that may be unusual, but acts as a dysfunctional family.

I saw it in Europe-plex . Great movie ! ! This film is an exploration of the Spirit and the human condition, set against the beautiful and enchanting backdrop of Europe. The intertwining stories and dynamic characters captivate the viewer, while tackling complex themes of love, hope, dreams, and loss. The breathtaking cinematography immerses you in this journey, making every twist and turn more powerful and poignant. Coupled with an evocative and atmospheric soundtrack, the film invites you into a world that resonates with viewers long after they have left the Europe-plex theater.

Personally, I regard "The Egyptian" in an extremely favourable light.It was introduced to me by a well-known Australian movie commenter & critic named Bill who was renowned for his insight & broad vision of people & places & particularly of films. This movie fitted the Bill perfectly & I came to appreciate his commentary & enthusiasm for this movie that emerged all the more as I watched it, as I was literally drawn into it, minute by minute, beyond his introductory comments, on my initial viewing many years ago.To me, it was propelled, layer upon layer, within half an hour, into an intriguing & fascinating production!

I have n't seen a film in a long time that moved me and gripped me in such a way as this one did. From the visually stunning cinematography to the deeply compelling storyline, I found myself entirely immersed in this cinematic masterpiece. The incredible performances by the talented ensemble of actors had me emotionally invested, resonating with their vulnerability and internal conflicts. I walked out of the theatre with an insatiable yearning to delve further into this captivating world and the complexities of its characters. It's a truly unforgettable experience, and one that has reinvigorated my appreciation for the art of filmmaking.

At first I could n't tell if it was an art film or a documentary . The day after I watched it, I was still pondering about the thought-provoking content and visuals. This masterpiece seemed to blur the boundaries between fiction and reality, keeping the audience in constant curiosity. The cinematography, coupled with an ambient musical score, successfully merged the realm of fine arts and factual accounts. This innovative fusion challenged the conventional understanding of cinema, pushing viewers to engage more critically with its content. Consequently, the film effortlessly struck a powerful chord with many viewers, leaving a lasting impact that undoubtedly transformed the landscape of visual storytelling.

Obviously inspired by Se7en and sometimes even more gruesome; more bloodshed and very graphic details (a bit too much for my taste). Great script and acting (I was especially impressed by Ken Stott and there were no weak points in te cast). Good cinematography and very realistic stereo-sound. One of the best thrillers I've seen since years. Although it was scheduled on BBC in three parts I watched Messiah on video in one take. One point of critic; the motivation of the villain was not very convincing.

One of the better made for TV biopics , I just wish it had told us more . I have always been a fan of biopics that delve deep into a person's life, providing insight into their character and accomplishments. While this particular production was visually pleasing with high production values and convincing acting, it fell short in providing a comprehensive account of the individual's story. Though the limited runtime is understandable for TV constraints, more exploration of their journey could have enriched the overall narrative. Hopefully, future projects will take this opportunity to fully encapsulate a person's extraordinary life, leaving viewers more informed and captivated.

This was the one movie to see about the Civi War. My aunt actually played in this movie as an extra in the Justin and Madeline wedding scene, and my uncle was an extra on a horse. The script was genuine, and accurate. The costumes were tastefully done, the seqence was in order and even the accents were good. I dearly love Patrick Swayze and James Ried. They were the best 2 choices, and it even had a great supporting cast. The Civil War is my favorite thing in American History, and I love movies about it.

After a summer full of retreads and disappointments, Nurse Betty is a breath of fresh air. The film is like no other I have ever seen. Director Neil LaBute proves that he can direct more then disturbing pictures of men and women and how they approach sex (his previous two films were the brillant In the Company of Men, and the almost brillant Your Friends and Neighbors). Renee Zellweger gives the best performance of her career as Betty, a waitress who, when she witnessing the brutal death of her asshole husband (LaBute mainstay Aaron Eckhart), and gets lost in a fantasy world.

Along with virtually every Republic Picture ever made , `` Murder in the Music Hall '' seems to have undeservably fallen into obscurity over the years. This 1946 musical-mystery film directed by John English presents an engaging plot revolving around the world of music, suspense, and hidden motives. While the star-studded cast delivered memorable performances, with performances by legendary singer Vera Hruba Ralston and iconic detective figure, Warner Baxter, the movie still remains somewhat underappreciated. This often-overlooked classic combines both the glamour and thrill of its time while encapsulating an atmospheric vintage experience.

I don't think I have ever seen a better movie parody. Mel Brooks is insane. EVERY time I watch it I find something new and it makes it even more funny than the time before. Cary Elwes is perfect for the role of Robin Hood. It has a great and unexpected ending that leaves you cracking up. Every character is great from Little John and Will to Maid Marian and Broomhilde. I laughed the whole way through and will never get tired of it. Watch it! !If you liked Cary Elwes in this Movie, you must definitely see The Princess Bride.

i really love this movie , i saw it for the first time when i was working a video store back in the early 2000s. It's incredible how much movies can shape our emotions and connections. At the time, I didn't have many friends and this movie filled that void, giving me a sense of belonging. I can still remember watching it in the backroom during my break with some microwave popcorn, completely drawn in by the compelling storyline and phenomenal performances. The amazing cinematography captivated me, and as each scene unfolded, it felt like I was there alongside the characters.

Me and my roommate got free tickets for a Pre Screening I guess you would call it in Atlanta, GA at Atlantic Station. Walking in I was expecting something controversial, provocative, unnecessarily overdone, etc.. But the film is much more than that. It's a story of two people helping each other. It's not overdone, and the film is done in a careful balance as to not make you cringe or say its unnecessary.It's put together really well and doesn't take itself too seriously. Thats the beauty of it.

Guess a few upscale film directors were sitting around sipping their absinthe , grappa , aramangac or jungle juice some years ago, pondering over potential box-office smashes that would cater to the whims and tastes of a discerning audience. As their conversations got infused with the spirit(s) of inspiration and avant-garde, they entertained each other with ideas as eclectic and diverse as their beverage menu, ranging from fantastical surrealist dreamscapes, neo-noir crime dramas, heart-tugging emotional stories, and immersive cinematic adventures filled with stunning visuals, remarkable scores, and masterful storytelling that aimed to hold global cinephiles captive.

My wife and I saw this when we were 17 . The only good thing my father ever did ( besides marrying my mother) was introducing us to this film. We were instantly drawn into its unique world and powerful story, cementing our lifelong bond through a shared passion for cinema. Over the years, this film became an essential part of our life together, a common touchstone that fostered understanding and closeness. Watching it evokes warm memories of the excitement and optimism of youth, the nostalgic feeling of growing and evolving together, and the unmistakable spark that has kept us together for decades.

Recently I saw this movie again ( after 25 years ) . In the original there is a scene in which a group of friends are all having dinner together, laughing and enjoying each other's company. Seeing this now brought back so many fond memories of my youth ‚Äì spending time with close friends, sharing countless stories and forging everlasting bonds. Despite the nostalgic sentiment, I also noticed how the movie‚Äôs storytelling, style and the societal contexts presented now seemed rather dated, allowing me to reflect on how times and cultures have significantly changed over the years.

Our Family and friends enjoyed this movie very much . The theme was well handled by the Director with great sensitivity and skill, effectively engaging the audience throughout the entire film. The well-developed storyline was presented seamlessly and maintained a consistent balance of emotion, humor, and thought-provoking scenes that appealed to viewers of all ages. Moreover, the captivating performances by the talented cast elevated the movie experience, leaving everyone profoundly impacted. The captivating visuals and crisp cinematography, accompanied by a masterful musical score, immersed us further into the journey of the characters.
