Unearthing personal letters and journals, Block manages to delicately unpack and portray the complexity and vulnerability that accompany marriage and family dynamics. 51 Birch Street transcends conventional storytelling to pose intriguing questions about relationships, loyalty, and communication. It beautifully captures the intricacies of the human condition through the lens of a single family, shedding light on what truly binds people together for better or for worse.

This is definitely one of the better Mel Brooks movies , along with Spaceballs ( although I will openly admit that Blazing Saddles still holds the top spot for me). As with most Brooks films, History of the World: Part I delivers that familiar mix of slapstick comedy, pun-filled dialogue, and no shortage of farcical antics. While it may not appeal to everyone's taste in humor, those who appreciate classic Mel Brooks shenanigans will not be disappointed. With an ensemble cast, featuring stars like Madeline Kahn and Gregory Hines, there's bound to be something for everyone who is up for a solid, zany good time.

Usually , Alan Alda plays characters that are too `` soft '' and overly verbal -- it 's probably how he earned the nickname "the thinking woman's heartthrob". But in reality, his seemingly mild persona conceals a man with substantial depth, nuance, and a wide emotional range. Throughout his extensive acting career, Alda has captivated audiences with not just his verbal prowess, but also his impeccable delivery and seamless transformations into every character he portrayed. As an actor and humanitarian, Alan Alda exudes a striking charisma that transcends the label of "soft".

I Love this movie ! I know some people might say that it was not a great movie , but for me, it was just what I needed at the time. The storyline was engaging, the acting was spot-on, and the music perfectly complimented the scenes. I understand that it may not cater to everyone's taste, but isn't that the beauty of films? It provided an escape and evoked a whirlwind of emotions for me. Maybe it's the nostalgic charm of certain scenes or perhaps just the cinematic experience, but this movie resonates with me deeply.

Honestly, when I went to see this movie at the Rave theater in Plainfield Indiana, I did not expect much. I went to this movie only because I figured hey, it's a WWE movie it'll be good for a laugh. Then I sat down and watched it and saw why they chose Glen Jacobs (Kane) to play Jacob Goodnight. He is probably one of the freakiest guys on the big screen (much worse in my opinion than Freddy or Jason) and has one big advantage to other movies that attracts me to a horror movie.

This film , released in 1951 , has the usual elements typical of the westerns released during the 50 's : rugged landscapes, galloping horses, gunfights, and cowboys trying to assert dominance. In the plot, the courageous and righteous protagonist confronts the town's antagonist ‚Äì a cruel, cold-blooded outlaw ‚Äì ultimately fighting for justice and his love interest, the local sweetheart. Thematic twists of revenge, brotherhood, and love keep the audience captivated while the picture-perfect portrayal of a harsh desert frontier embeds the narrative in realism. Period-appropriate costume designs and character developments elevate the film and carve its distinct position in 1950's cinematic history.

for a movie like this little hidden gem to come out in the 80s , its shocking how not a lot of people know about it or even talk about it in conversations of classic 80s movies. A film that perfectly blends elements of drama, romance, and that nostalgic vintage charm, it truly stands the test of time in delivering an engaging narrative with richly layered characters that capture the hearts of the viewers. One can only imagine the cultural impact this film would have had if it received the spotlight it truly deserved.

The Truth and Reconciliation process in South Africa is a vital and probably unique human experiment . This movie does an incredible job of delving into the depths of this extraordinary journey towards healing and understanding in a deeply divided nation. Based on real events and testimonials, the film focuses on the courage, strength and perseverance of individuals who shared their stories in front of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. From harrowing tales of pain, suffering and loss to inspiring stories of redemption and forgiveness, the movie sheds light on the remarkable power of the human spirit, embracing the complexities and difficult lessons this powerful process unveiled.

This was on odd film . I liked the adventure of it though it seems to be aimed at children and is definitely family-friendly. The vibrant characters and whimsical plotline may come across as juvenile to some, but they truly capture the essence of innocence and escapism. As the storyline unfolds, it incorporates underlying themes such as friendship, bravery, and self-discovery. These poignant messages provide an additional layer for the viewers to explore and resonate with, making it appealing to a wider audience. Despite the unusual and childish concept, this film ultimately enchants with its quirky charm and warmth, serving as a lighthearted reminder of simpler times.

there's only so much that i can take of Filipino films, especially nowadays where the trend is sex, action and slapstick comedy(which i hate). the fact that Nasaan Ka Man made me think and made me gape during the movie was a big plus. It's got good cinematic scenes and editing was great, especially the cinematography. i think that Claudine deserves the best actress here rather than getting one in the movie Milan. the fact that there's only so few Filipino movies that i really like. i think Cholo Laurel did such a great job in this movie.

The film starts with promise because there is more interaction between Spanky and Buckwheat, but as the film progresses, the two boys have fewer scenes together. This slows the pace considerably. Billie "Buckwheat" Thomas gives a very strong performance in his early scenes. When he is left behind on the riverboat, his fear and abandonment are palpable and his tears are truly heartbreaking. When he goes from man to man asking for help and is repeatedly rejected the viewer really begins to wonder if this is a comedy or not. Watching a children's birthday party through a picket fence is another moving moment.

I Love this movie! I know some people might say that it was not a great movie, but I really disagree. The comedy is classic Mel Brooks style and the actors were superbly chosen. This was my first exposure to Cary Elwes, and Dave Chappelle and what a first impression they made. Cary Elwes shines as Robin Hood, the only British Robin Hood mind you. He has great comedic timing and the right attitude for this type of film. Dave Chappelle is obviously much bigger now, but at the time this was his first movie and he did an outstanding job as Achoo.

I saw this movie when it was first released and thoroughly enjoyed it . What a movie . I am amazed at how well it has aged over the years! The brilliant storytelling, powerful performances, and mesmerizing cinematography have withstood the test of time. Not only does it deliver pure entertainment, but it also offers subtle life lessons and messages that resonate deeply with the audience. Every time I watch this masterpiece, I find myself more absorbed in the story and invested in the characters, uncovering new nuances and hidden gems I might have missed on previous viewings.

Renee Zellweger is Betty, a Kansas waitress who wants to be a nurse, who is infatuated with a soap opera actor (Greg Kinnear), and who is married to Del, a cheating, stupid male chauvinist who's trying to sell some stolen drugs. Unfortunately for him, he gets brutally, bloodily murdered instead, while Betty secretly watches. It leaves her unhinged, believing that Kinnear is really the character he plays, Dr. David Ravell, and that she is his RN ex-fianc√©e. She heads for LA to find her lost love, not knowing the stolen drugs are in her trunk.

` Skenbart ' is one of the funniest movies to not only to come from Peter Dalle but from the entire Swedish film industry as well. This delightful comedy masterpiece delivers non-stop laughter and an engaging storyline that leaves audiences entertained from start to finish. With its brilliantly written script and impressive cast performances, 'Skenbart' manages to strike the perfect balance between wit and slapstick humor, creating memorable moments throughout the film. Showcasing the best of Scandinavian cinema, it truly stands the test of time and serves as an essential addition to any movie lover's collection.

This as the first of the Ma and Pa Kettle flicks. Marjorie Main (Ma) steals the show in anything she does. Funny to see Ida Moore as Emily, the daffy old lady on the train.. god she was ALWAYS old; she was in "Desk Set" and "Alfred Hitchcock Presents". Their new house is also a co-star here -- its the house of the future with some really cool inventions that Pa doesn't care for. LOVE the painting gag. Keep an eye out for TOM... he starred in "Nanny & the Professor".

I saw this fine flick shortly leaving college. As I sat there happily watching Alice go from repressed virgin to sexual adventurer, I got to wondering why her sexual encounters seemed familiar. Then I remembered-- Intro Psych 101 Lecture! One of the lectures dealt with the Psycho-Sexual Stages of Developement, basically the shift over time on what part of the body and its attendant stimulations gets our main attention, as well as the changing emphasis on what gives us pleasure. Alice's first encounter is being bathed, with emphasis on the genitals and bottom.

John Ford paid the wagons his tribute of a special picture, 'Wagon Master' made after two big Indian-cavalry epics... It is a lovely poetic movie, full of romanticized reincarnation of the pioneer spirit... It didn't have to top the big ones that had preceded it...Photographically, it is extremely simple... The camera moves only once or twice in the entire film, and never when a director would have made it move to underline a shot... Ford even resists the temptation to track his camera in the breathtaking twilight shots of the women wearily marching along in the dust behind their wagons...

This film blew me away . I thought I knew a little about the Attica prison riot . After watching this documentary, I realized there was so much more to learn. The detailed accounts of the uprising, the inmates' motivations, and the authorities' mishandling of the situation provide a powerful narrative. The director captures raw emotions and delves deep into the complexities surrounding the incident, showing it as a symbol of the struggle for human rights and dignity. In addition, the film brings to light previously undisclosed facts, forcing the viewer to confront issues of justice, race, and civil liberties.

In the midst of a documentary about his parents , the filmmaker 's mother dies , but he continues making the film as a tribute to both his parents. As the narrative unfolds, the documentary turns into a deeply personal exploration of love, grief, and healing. Combining intimate interviews, candid conversations, and cherished home movies, the filmmaker delves into his family's history, seeking a better understanding of his mother and a renewed connection with his grieving father. Simultaneously, the documentary raises questions about the fragility of life and the perseverance of human connections in times of adversity.

If this is not my favorite movie of all time , it definitely is in the top five . I simply cannot get enough of its brilliant storytelling, compelling characters, and the stunning visual effects. Each time I watch it, I discover a new aspect that adds even more depth and dimension to the storyline. The acting is superb, and I'm continually impressed by the attention to detail in the set design and costuming. This film manages to pull me into its immersive world and truly makes me care about the fate of its characters, evoking a range of emotions that keep me coming back for more.

I actually went to see this movie with low expectations since it was the only one that fit my schedule and the reviews had been mixed. Surprisingly, I found myself thoroughly entertained and invested in the characters' stories. The plot may have had a few predictable moments, but the unexpected twists and compelling performances more than made up for it. The film also showcased stunning visuals, leaving me in awe at certain scenes. Despite the movie's length, the pacing was steady and never lost my interest. Ultimately, the movie exceeded my initial expectations and made for a highly enjoyable viewing experience.

Fuckland is an interesting film. I personally love the Dogma movement. I wish it had lasted longer. It seems to have already died. Many critics tried their damndest to shut it down. I don't know why. It's the most interesting movement to happen in the cinematic world since the French New Wave. Besides Fuckland, I've seen the first three in the series, Festen, Idioterne, and Mifune. They were all great, Festen being a masterpiece, in my opinion. Fuckland isn't up to those others. I was just fascinated with the filmmaking.

It has been recorded that John Ford made the "big, blockbuster" movies so that he could afford to make the "small" movies that he loved so well. Wagon Master, with a young Ben Johnson, is clearly one of his best, if not the best of his small movies. The location shooting, the wagons, the intricate work with horses, and the inclusion of the plains Indian are all trade marks of Ford. As in many of his other films, Eisenstein, the great Russian director's influence is seen in this film.

Working at a movie theater as a projectionist , I have the opportunity to watch basically every movie that comes out. There's something magical about watching films in an empty auditorium, each frame lighting up the entire space. Although being a projectionist can become monotonous at times, it's undeniably rewarding. The unique perspective of witnessing each production unfold, coupled with the mechanics and intricacies of running a projector, truly lends an insider's perspective into the world of cinema. On some occasions, fellow staff members even join me for a personal screening, enhancing my understanding of diverse movie preferences and cultivating shared memories we can cherish together.

The Tempest has been interpreted in many different ways ranging from more or less traditional views as dealing with Art and Nature, Colonization and Civilization, or as an allegory on political power struggles. Other interpretations have examined it as an exploration of human identity, metaphysical self-discovery, and the complex dynamic between the rational and the instinctual self. Additionally, some consider The Tempest to be an example of the nascent genre of tragicomedy, with its skillful weaving of comedic elements within an essentially dramatic framework. Moreover, contemporary performances of the play often emphasize eco-criticism and the play's potential insights into post-colonial issues.

It happens often , while growing up , a Hollywood movie impresses a youth . It not only lasts a lifetime but can potentially influence their entire way of life. In many cases, these films can become more than just a mere source of entertainment. They transform into cultural staples and timeless pieces of art that mold future generations with their thought-provoking content, innovative storytelling techniques, and groundbreaking performances. In this regard, the power of cinema is remarkable, leaving indelible impressions on young minds, which later evolve into core values and ideologies that define their personalities, aspirations, and contribution to society.

This is a luminously photographed and unusually well-written western by veteran creator of "Rawhide" Charles Marquis Warren. Direcxtor Gordon Douglas is its chief help in this regard. Its strong plot line can be told in a few sentences. A hard-nosed by-the- book, Cavalry officer, Captain Richard Lance, captures a leader of the Indian enemy after a massacre at a fort. He insists on bringing the man back for trial, to be sent toTucson; his commander sends another man to try to take the prisoner for trial and the patrol is wiped out.

I'm absolutely disgusted this movie isn't being sold. All who love this movie should email Disney and increase the demand for it. They'd eventually have to sell it then. I'd buy copies for everybody I know. Everything and everybody in this movie did a good job, and I haven't figured out why Disney hasn't put this movie on DVD or on VHS in rental stores. At least I haven't seen any copies. This is a wicked good movie and should be seen by all. The kids in the new generation don't get to see it and I think they should.

... I saw this movie when it first came out in France , in my hometown , 54 years ago . I still remember the excitement in the air, the sense of magic in that little theater. People lined up outside, buzzing about the storyline and actors. My friends and I could hardly contain ourselves as we took our seats, clutching the coveted tickets in our hands. The moment the lights dimmed and the projector started, the audience was instantly transported into another world. The performances, the cinematography, and the riveting storyline still remain engraved in my memories, serving as a constant reminder of that thrilling time.

The hurried approach that Lewis Seiler takes with King of the Underworld establishes a deeper plot, while still maintaining an efficient run-time. One of the clearest examples of this is the transition between poverty and wealth for the married medical couple. The audience is instantly transported from a shanty medical office to a luxurious suite at the city's most prestigious inn. This development is critical to understanding the position the doctors have been thrown into. The story suggests from the intro that these two people are generally happy with providing medical practice to those who are less fortunate.

Most of these reviews are dead on, so I'll cut to a different chase and answer a couple of questions I've seen on here.While the characters seem and look young (hence the controversy), the actor/actress themselves were 17 and 18 at the time and so obviously over the 16 barrier. Here in the USA, that's still somewhat controversial but the simplicity and innocence of the film does much to offset it.I'm sorry not to have seen more by Sean; in this movie at least his expressions are demonstrative and obvious; you know exactly what the character is feeling whether he's angry, afraid, or confused.

Surprisingly good made for T.V. Thriller. I wasn't expecting too much from this one but I'm glad to say that this is one of the best of it's kind. It's fast paced and features solid acting and interesting events. The story gets you hooked on since the beginning and with many hits, you can't help but find the movie very interesting.The background story of Thiessen's character is hard but it turns into a nightmare when her husband is something much worse than her childhood friend's step father.The "stranger" concept and his actions are disturbing if you consider that it is a common disease in society.

I haven't seen this movie since it came out at a drive in theater, and I have been searching for it since. At the time I was 12 and the story excited me; and NOW, the ending eludes me. It was young love that engrossed me the most, not to mention John's vocals and Taupin's lyrics. The story (at the time) hit home to my psyche. I am a lover of sentimental movies and this still hangs in my head after 35 years- it is that good. Place yourself at adolescent age and let your fantasies run.

Having reviewed 3 of the 4 Perry and Croft sitcoms, I thought I would get them all done now. Dads Army, is my all time favourite sitcom, It ain't half hot Mum is also a classic as is You Rang M'Lord. I don't regard Hi De Hi as a classic, but it is still funny.It's about a holiday camp, similar to Butlins, but instead of red coats, it's yellow coats. It is ran by Jeffery Fairbrother, a well meaning man, but has the personality of a sock.

Having grown up in the typing pool era and dealing with office politics and men who were apt to make inappropriate advances, Marjorie became an expert in handling any challenging work environment with a steely demeanor. It wasn't just about the typewriter or being fast at shorthand, it was more about learning to command respect and create a presence of quiet authority in male-dominated spaces. Marjorie's career had evolved greatly as gender dynamics began shifting in the workplace, her wisdom earned over the years proving invaluable for both her career success and personal growth.

This game is very good for the n64 . You can skate as Tony Hawk , Bob Burnquist , Steve Caballero, and other legendary skaters. The gameplay is incredibly smooth, with precise controls and physics that truly capture the thrill and excitement of professional skateboarding. It includes a variety of modes such as Career, Free Skate, and multiplayer, making it perfect for endless hours of enjoyment. One of the best aspects of the game is its level design. Each map offers challenging tasks, hidden secret areas, and exceptional tricks to keep the game fresh and engaging.

In December 1945 a train leaves the central station of Stockholm for Berlin. There aren't much left when it arrives. Not of the train and not of some passengers.This is a black comedy directed by Peter Dalle and acted like they used to act in the 40s and also photographed (in b/w) like they used to during that period. The actors must have had lots of fun making it. They aren't much of characters, like they weren't in the 40s, but the story is well narrated and everybody has timing.A deadly black and deadly funny film.

Even for a 17 year old student who loves history and caught glimpses of emotion and excitement in his childhood years of this series, its coming to DVD was a blessing for all time. North and South truly is a series about friendship,love,honor... you name your own list of feelings you get from watching this series. I can still remember the first time I caught a glimpse of this series on TV when I was about 8 years old. I though wow this looks exciting. To bad I never had the chance to see book one and two on TV in the Netherlands.

For my money, probably the best film - or at least the most purely cinematic film - director Ford ever made. The dialog is swift, clipped, to the point.l The story starts at the very beginning and only ends with the final credits. Ford uses a relatively small cast, but directs them and photographs them with a verve and a sweep of epic proportions. Grimly realistic, warmly amusing, brilliantly acted (hard to believe Johnsonj couldn't become a leading man after this), with the best photography and editing in any American black-and-white film.

spoiler--In 1993, African-American director/actor Mario Van Peebles followed up the tremendously popular urban-action film New Jack City with "Posse". The film was co-written and directed by Van Peebles, who also stars as the main character, Jessie Lee.Plot: The film begins at the turn of the 20th century, when the United States was embroiled in the Spanish-American war. Apparently a time when the U.S. justice system could send convicts into military service, Jessie Lee finds himself an unwilling enlisted man, serving with an all-black cavalry troop in Cuba.

I saw this movie back in 1954 on a double-bill with `` Valley of the Kings . '' These movies were the highlights of my summer as a young teen, evoking a sense of adventure and discovery. Both films showcased exotic locations that ignited my wanderlust, despite the low-budget productions. In the movie, the protagonists faced seemingly insurmountable challenges and braved through desolate deserts, as they pursued legendary artifacts hidden within ancient Egyptian tombs. The vivid storytelling coupled with my impressionable age led me to develop a lasting fascination with archaeology, mysteries of the past, and cinematic narratives that unfold in enthralling settings.

There 's a unique place in the pantheon of John Ford films for Wagonmaster , Sergeant Rutledge , and The Sun Shines Bright - each stands as a distinct testament to Ford's skill as a storyteller and his love for complex characters that challenge and expand the understanding of the American mythos. While Wagonmaster pays homage to pioneering spirits venturing into unknown lands, Sergeant Rutledge presents a deeply nuanced portrait of racial prejudices as the backdrop of an engaging courtroom drama. The Sun Shines Bright, on the other hand, tenderly deals with social redemption set in postbellum Southern society.

Maybe it's just a personal affection for this screen version of the Mika Waltari novel, or a fondness for things Egyptian (I grew up loving to visit the mummies in Boston's Museum of Fine Arts) but I think Maltin is a tad tough on this rather good film. The production values are great regarding color and cinematography, and it appears some effort went into historical authenticity (much of it from the novel, I'm sure). Purdom is admittedly a bit stiff in the lead role, but one can accept this as part of Sinuhe's character.

I have to say that this film was excellently produced and tops the ratings as a typical sci fi film , blending elements of thrilling action, gripping storytelling, and compelling characters. The CGI and visual effects are stunning, immersing the viewer in the movie's futuristic universe. Moreover, the plot unravels at a gripping pace, holding one's attention throughout. The cast also delivers strong performances that evoke genuine emotions, with thought-provoking dialogue providing an intriguing exploration of the human experience. The production value, combined with meticulous attention to detail, places this film among the classics of the sci-fi genre, offering viewers an unforgettable experience.

Watching The Wagonmaster is not likely to result in deep thoughts , unlike many other great Ford films , like The Grapes of Wrath or The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance, which leave the audience pondering on powerful societal issues. Nevertheless, The Wagonmaster should not be overlooked, as it remains an engaging and visually impressive portrayal of the Old West, capturing the spirit of perseverance and camaraderie among settlers. With picturesque landscape shots and iconic horse chases, it delivers an appealing tale of personal triumph in the face of adversity, allowing the viewer to sit back and enjoy the adventurous spirit of classic Hollywood westerns.

It 's interesting to watch how late 1950 's society is depicted in this film . Men are lecherous , sexually aggressive, and prone to crude behavior while women are submissive and often objectified. It seems as if a significant focus of their existence revolves around adhering to societal norms, be it by putting up with men's disrespectful antics or restraining their desires for career ambitions. This film provides a revealing glimpse into a time where casual sexism and toxic masculinity seemed to prevail, while also serving as a sharp reminder of how much our society has transformed.

i love this show ! it is amazing ... i can never miss an episode even if i 've already watched it multiple times. The plot twists keep me hooked, and the character development is truly outstanding. Every episode manages to surprise me in a different way and constantly leaves me wanting more. The writers, actors, and production team are incredibly talented and perfectly bring the story to life. Plus, the amazing balance of humor, emotion, and suspense is addictive! This show is definitely one of the best I've ever seen, and I will proudly recommend it to everyone I know.

Okay, where to begin. Did you know that the part of the lead robots were offered to famous mime team Shields and Arnez? Bet ya didn't. But they turned it down complaining about robot make-up. Then they faded off into obscurity. Now, this movie has everything. A crazed killer robot who thinks he's dirty Harry. Lots of cool robots. It's funny, it's touching, it's the perfect date movie for people who love sci-fi and romantic comedies. It's the first robot romantic comedy. Now of course very few movies are perfect and there are some character issues.

The Hookers was to me a great everyday people story, Like someone you might have known. Just trying to make it, my big shot is right around the corner. Then Life's little temptations creep in, the spoiler, stumbled again. How much, can your love take, and give, to the guy who's really not so bad, after all, just Human. I liked it, I was also a paid extra in the movie. Played the drums in the bar shots, with the band, did several walking shots, my green 66' corvette was in the motel party shots.

The whole shorthand for supposedly being more aware in this weird time is that you are `` Blue '' . In today's fast-paced world, there seems to be an increasing desire to be more conscious, present and knowledgeable about the ongoing issues. Hence, to symbolize this new wave of enlightenment and wisdom, we commonly use the color ``Blue''. To be ``Blue'' signifies that one is deeply perceptive of both internal and external circumstances, acutely conscious about life and its complexities, and possess an open mindset that helps them sift through all that is odd, contradictory or complicated.

If I'd only seen the poster for Nurse Betty, I probably wouldn't have touched it with a ten-foot pole. But after I heard some positive buzz, and knowing it made some noise at Cannes, I decided to give it a try. What I got is a truly enjoyable movie, based on a very entertaining plot. Rene Zelleweger is impressive in her role as ¬ënurse' Betty, a woman who is sent into a delusional psychotic episode following a traumatic experience. I also liked Morgan Freeman (no surprise) and was pleasantly surprised by foul-mouthed comedian Chris Rock.

I first saw this film when I was in the 8th grade and I remember that it had a profound impact on me at that age. The compelling story, powerful performances, and skillful cinematography really drew me in and held my attention throughout. Watching it made me truly appreciate the art of storytelling and the ways that films can transport viewers into different worlds and situations. As I reflect on this experience now, I realize that this film sparked a lifelong passion for cinema, and perhaps even played a role in influencing my current career path.

The Box is one of the strangest movies I have ever seen . To explain my experience , let me start by describing its eerie and thought-provoking plot. The movie begins with a suburban couple, Arthur and Norma, receiving a mysterious box with a large red button. Alongside the box comes an enigmatic man, presenting them with an unsettling proposition - they must choose whether to push the button or not. The consequences? Someone they don't know will die, but in return, they'll receive a life-altering sum of $1 million.

A train holding union soldiers is transporting $ 300,000 of gold , along with a banker Clayton , who 's responsible for ensuring the safe delivery of the precious cargo. The train sets off on its perilous journey across enemy territory, teeming with Confederate ambushes and unexpected obstacles. As tension builds among the passengers, whispers of betrayal and conspiracy grow louder, prompting the ever-vigilant Clayton to remain constantly on alert. Amidst their mission, the Union soldiers must band together to guard the gold, unmask the mole on board, and dodge impending Confederate attacks.

This film had me spellbound this evening . Thanks to Fox Movie Classics for showing it uninterrupted . John Voight and Burt Reynolds were brilliant in their respective roles. The on-screen chemistry between the lead actors kept me thoroughly engrossed throughout the film. The stunning cinematography captured the raw beauty and intensity of the story, while the suspenseful score kept my heart racing at each turn. The director deserves praise for bringing together such a talented ensemble cast and eliciting remarkable performances from each of them. All in all, I'm grateful for this incredible experience and highly recommend it to everyone who loves classic cinema.

The Box is one of the strangest movies I have ever seen. To explain my experience, let me use this word picture: Imagine that you have been binging on pixie sticks and paint fumes for the last month while watching nothing but Twilight Zone reruns. The resulting coma lands you in a hospital, where the nurse seems to get a kick out of shooting adrenalin into your IV. The dream that you have while in the coma will be something like this movie.SUMMARY: A man shows up at the door of a couple. He gives them a box with a button on it.

Fata Morgana is , by far , one of the weirdest and most perplexing art films I have ever seen Fata Morgana is, by far, one of the weirdest and most perplexing art films I have ever seen. It stretches the limits of convention with its bizarre imagery, ethereal soundtrack, and peculiar narrative. Directed with purposeful ambiguity, it presents a non-linear storyline, which further fuels a deep curiosity that cannot be easily shaken off. Although it might be too obtuse for some, it is an essential watch for those with a proclivity for experimental cinema.

I caught this flick on the trail end of a tape I had used to capture a movie I truly wanted to see, and, to my surprise, it turned out to be an absolute hidden gem. A brilliantly made feature, overflowing with impressive performances and a thought-provoking, beautifully intricate plot that I simply couldn't get enough of. As the tape played on, I was engulfed into a captivating cinematic journey which thoroughly debunked the adage 'never judge a book by its cover,' in this case, a random VHS I happened to stumble upon.

Excellent entry in the RKO Saint series with well-written original script, good camera work and transitions, good directing to handle some twists in the plot, good editing to keep the flow constant, and good acting. George Sanders is suave and witty. Jonathan Hale simply is Inspector Fernack. Paul Guilfoyle plays a mobster who goes straight (and drinks milk) because he cannot take the pressure. He will return in a later entry in the series. Story begins on an ocean liner headed to the U.S. where the Saint meets but cannot connect with Wendie Barrie.

Rabbit Seasoning is one of three cartoons that feature Bugs Bunny/Daffy Duck/Elmer Fudd in a war of words and wits over hunting season. In this hilarious and iconic Merrie Melodies animation, released in 1952, Bugs Bunny cleverly tricks his arch-rival, Daffy Duck, into arguing with dim-witted hunter Elmer Fudd about which season it truly is‚Äîduck or rabbit. Employing a series of brilliantly comedic tactics and wild misdirections, Bugs never fails to amaze viewers with his trademark sass and cunning schemes. This memorable escapade encapsulates the classic charm of these unforgettable characters, while showcasing the intelligent humor of early animation.

Robin Hood ; Men in Tights is worth watching , I recently watched it because I 've just become a huge fan of classic comedy films. This movie, directed by Mel Brooks, is a hilarious parody of the traditional Robin Hood story. Cary Elwes plays Robin Hood flawlessly, and the humor is endless. The film skillfully blends elements of slapstick, wordplay, and situational comedy. It is lighthearted and the witty dialogue makes it even more enjoyable. For fans of comedy and classic legends, this film is a must-watch. Give yourself a break from serious movies, and dive into this rib-tickling comedic gem!

Watching this film caused quite an emotional reaction. This is what today's documentaries are all about. It's refreshing to watch something so personal, honest and real. Mr. Block's thoughts, opinions and disclosure are rarely seen these days and are incredibly well displayed here. It's a fine line to walk between personal truth and exploitation. This film treads very carefully and quite successfully.One would think that learning about how a seemingly normal couple falls short of society's expectations would give birth to pessimism...but it doesn't. Quite the opposite: it made me feel good.

I saw this movie for the first time a little over a year ago . I 've seen it 4 times since then, and it just gets better with every watch. The plot is gripping and the acting is top-notch. The storyline, characters, and dialogues feel so natural and compelling that you simply cannot take your eyes off the screen. I particularly love the score, which sets the mood perfectly and elevates the overall cinematic experience. In fact, every technical aspect, from cinematography to sound design, is brilliant.

This was on odd film. I liked the adventure of it though it seems to be aimed at children. (SPOILER AHEAD) Ironically, the main character murders a federal official. Then he's a fugitive on the run. They later blow up his house and then he finally commits suicide. Seems like they should have just made it a film for a more mature audience or made it more family friendly.This was on odd film. I liked the adventure of it though it seems to be aimed at children. (SPOILER AHEAD) Ironically, the main character murders a federal official.

I would probably not have bothered to comment on this film if I had not been disturbed by the constant references made to it here in North America as a porn film. Our obsession with what is, or should be, regarded as pornographic remains a relic of the 'guidance' provided to film makers by the Hayes committee many, many years ago and it is now really time that we relegate it to the past. So far we have not progressed far beyond establishing a somewhat arbitrary division between what we now term 'soft' and 'hard' porn, with both carrying the same pornography label.

This if the first movie I've given a 10 to in years. If there was ever a movie that needed word-of-mouth to promote, this is it. A $4 Mil box is a disgrace. People don't know what it's about. If you have any appreciation for the Blues, or just a good use of excellent music, that alone is reason to go see it. How many people knew Jackson could sing, and damn fine too. You hear books and movies taunting that they're about salvation. After seeing this, you'll never be able to forgive such trivial use of the word.

The trailer to this film focused so much on the chain (of course, because it's so sensational) that it missed most of the movie, which is about a developing, although rather simply drawn, relationship between Lazarus and Rae as they attempt to recover from their past pains with each other.Of course, with the premise of a nymphomaniac in chains, it's no surprise that there's plenty of implied sex involved. However, at it's core, Black Snake Moan is a basic tale of redemption and the healing power of helping another person along.

Graphics is far from the best part of the game . This is the number one best TH game in the series, mainly because it boasts excellent gameplay mechanics, engaging storylines, and an incredibly immersive world that the player can get lost in for hours on end. Despite the less-than-stellar graphics, players will quickly be drawn to the well-developed characters, innovative level designs, and smooth controls that make it a satisfying experience for all. In addition, the game features an impressive and diverse soundtrack, contributing to a thrilling atmosphere.

honestly.. this show warms my heart, i watch it EVERYDAY on fox family and now that the new season has started i'm even more hooked than before.. the characters are so well-developed and their relationships are so real.. i would recommend this show for any woman or mother and daughter.. the Lorelei's are super fast talking witty girls that will, truly inspire you and the show is hysterical at times and never too too serious, but serious enough for it to be completely addicting.. it's an hour long which is a major PLUS because you can't ever get enough Gilmore!

This was another great episode from season 11 of South Park. Cartman fakes having Tourette syndrome in order to be able to say whatever he wants without getting in trouble. He is able to swear at the other kids at school. Kyle tells the Principal that Cartman is faking it. But, she doesn't believe it. Chris Hansen is planning on having Cartman to be on Dateline to talk about Tourette syndrome live and uncensored. But later on, Cartman starts to get so addicted to be able to say whatever he wants, that he later on starts to accidentally say embarrassing stuff.

I did n't have very high expectations about Just Before Dawn . I do n't know why I keep buying these low-budget horror flicks, but something about them always intrigues me. So, I popped it into the DVD player on a gloomy evening, fully prepared for the usual clich√©s and amateur acting. Surprisingly, Just Before Dawn ended up being an enjoyable watch. It definitely had its fair share of cringe-worthy moments, but overall the plot was gripping, and the actors gave more convincing performances than expected. Plus, the setting added a sense of unease which kept me on the edge of my seat.

If this is not my favorite movie of all time, it definitely is in the top five. I love this. Everything about this is perfect--the clothes, the set, the lines--yes, they're not how normal people talk, but... Right down to the small scenes, especially at the beginning of the office girls changing their shoes, picking a wedgie, watering the office ivy plant, putting lunch in the fridge... Identical to what us office girls do today in the year 2005. I think all the minor characters are wonderful.

In dramatising Wilde 's novel , John Osborne has condensed events , eliminated a number of characters , and generally streamlined the narrative to create a more focused and intense theatrical experience. He has shifted emphasis on certain relationships, deepened emotional complexities, and accentuated the core themes of moral decadence, beauty, and corruption present in Wilde's original work. This adaptation hones in on the intense psychological conflict within the protagonist while keeping the satirical and ironic tone of Wilde's original. Furthermore, by seamlessly integrating the haunting presence of the supernatural, Osborne heightens the dramatic tension and lays bare the ever-present societal hypocrisies that drove Wilde's pen.

The best bit in the film was when Alan pulled down her knickers and ran the cut throat razor over her soft, sensitive skin. The tension in the room escalated as Alan masterfully controlled the thin, sharp blade with an exquisite delicacy, knowing that one wrong move could turn the scene into a gore fest. As beads of sweat trickled down his forehead, the rest of the group collectively held their breath, eagerly awaiting the big reveal. Once he was done, Alan slowly pulled out the stencil he'd stealthily placed, exposing the exquisite and intricate design skillfully shaved into the otherwise untouched fabric.

Having been interested in Akhenaton for many years I was surprised to learn about this film via E-bay and bought it immediately. Upon watching it, I discovered a fascinating portrayal of the ancient Egyptian pharaoh's life and reign. The film delves into Akhenaton's religious revolution, wherein he attempted to replace polytheism with monotheism, by exclusively worshiping the sun god Aten. The storyline also explores his relationships with Queen Nefertiti and their daughters, as well as the various conflicts and controversies of his rule. The visuals are stunning, accurately capturing ancient Egyptian culture and the complexities of this tumultuous period.

A rather charming depiction of European union beginning to operate among the young generation as representatives of that group learn to live together in an apartment in Barcelona, where they are all studying on international fellowships. Central to the story is Xavier ( Romain Duris),who may have lived a rather conventional life with his mother in France, but who quickly becomes a leader in the group, helping them deal with landlords and other problems. He learns about life and love rapidly. Duris has a wholesome appearance and gives a fine performance. The rest of the cast also play well.

I had always heard about this great mini-series, but viewed it for the first time this week, July of 2007. I can see why it started the careers of so many young actors. The story is intriguing and gives wonderful insights into the period before and during the Civil War. I cared about the characters and how their lives evolved during this period. Some of them were stereotypes, but they still helped me see how people thought during the 1800's. Many historical facts were thrown into the story and it was interesting to see history books come to life.

America 's next top model is a good show , it helps people with their careers , but lately i 've noticed some concerns regarding the show's approach towards contestants. The show emphasizes heavily on looks, and at times can promote an unhealthy body image among participants and viewers alike. The pressure to fit into a specific mold can take a toll on a contestant's mental and emotional health. Moreover, with the increasing emphasis on body positivity and inclusivity, the show should strive to break beauty stereotypes and encourage contestants from all backgrounds and body types.

This is a really great film ! It gets you thinking about your parents . How we all have fragile relationships with them, and how we take them for granted sometimes. The storyline delves deep into the complexities of parenthood and highlights the emotional struggles that they face in raising their children, who grow up and start leading their own lives. The characters are brilliantly portrayed, and the raw emotions they exhibit are extremely relatable. With an unexpected plot twist that leaves you on the edge of your seat, this film beautifully portrays the bittersweet bonds between parents and children.

"The bad dreams always come back again like unwanted friends," says Marion Fairlie, who with her half-sister, Laura, lives in a vast mid-Victorian country estate. "And last night I found myself in Limmeridge churchyard. Normally, people who are dead stay dead, just as normally it is the criminals who are locked up rather than the victims. But then, there was nothing normal about what happened to us..." And we're off on a first-class Gothic story of madness, deception and villainy, based on Wilkie Collins' great novel of Victorian mystery.

Ok, maybe Posse can't compare to other popular cowboy/western movies. But that's because it didn't have the FUNDING those movies had. Obviously, whenever you want to produce a story such as this one, focusing on African American historical involvement (and NO, servants and 'mammies' are not historical involvement), Hollywood isn't going to be too supportive. And believe me they weren't. The producers and actors sacrificed a lot of 'out of pocket' expenses to make "Posse", just so that the story could be told. I think that alone is commendable.

I was mighty impressed with Nurse Betty all the way through. It has a great ensemble of characters, an origional plot, and an ending I shoulda seen coming but didn't and pulls at your heart strings.If theres any one thing about this movie that got me the most it was Morgan Freeman and Chris Rock's interaction. These two are great and it warms my heart to see Rock isn't going to do crappy Big Hollywood fare like Lethal Weapon 4 for the rest of his life. Freeman is as always the man, really there shouldnt be any need to critique his work anymore.

The film begins with a cranky old Broadway producer (exceptionally well-played by veteran character actor Richard Carle) being driven by a man hoping to sell him a story for an upcoming play. However, there is a bad storm and their car becomes stuck in the mud and so they are forced to look for some place to spend the night. Fortunately, there's a mansion nearby though it seems pretty odd that the people inside know the writer and he says he didn't realize this was the home of a man he knew (and despised).

Cant believe it .... after all these years finally tracked this down .. it was meant to be named 'The Lost City', and was shrouded in mystery and legends. No map, no clear directions; just countless stories and brave souls seeking it. Delving deep into the dense forests, facing unknown perils, but driven by sheer determination and hope, the journey has been truly an epic adventure. Countless hours of decoding riddles, picking up hidden clues, and perseverance, paid off as I stood at the doorstep of 'The Lost City'. The sight before me ‚Äì astonishing and beyond imagination.

Obsessed!!!!! I have every season of Gilmore Girls and I think the reason I love it so much is because of how smart the script is, its not your average comedy show there isn't any pause after a joke it just keeps on, if you missed you missed it. And its not like a soap opera drama either because it doesn't use dramatic music and the actors never have those stupid cheesy surprise looks. I think Gilmore Girls is one of the bests shows on T.V. shows of its time.

The Further Adventures of Ma and Pa Kettle almost seamlessly picks up where The Egg and I left off . The Further Adventures of Ma and Pa Kettle delves deeper into the life of our beloved, quirky couple on their rustic farm. As Ma and Pa continue their colorful journey of family misadventures, new characters and challenging situations arise, providing much-needed excitement and chaos in their seemingly mundane rural existence. New dilemmas in their fields lead Ma and Pa to comically battle not just their capricious animals, but also the baffling farm equipment and bureaucracy, bringing about unforgettable experiences that solidify the unique charm of their dynamic relationship.

I saw the Messiah:- The First Killings and I thought it was absolutely one of the best programmes I have seen, ever. It was one of those programmes that you think that oh, no, I cannot watch the rest of this but you feel compelled to watch it just to see who done it. Jamie Draven was an absolutely amazing actor in it, to be able to switch between two totally, totally different characters one of which is the evil, nasty person that did it and the other person who is Jez Clifton, the cop.

Thank you Mario Van Peebles for informing us of not only the existence of black cowboys, but providing a compelling story that was easy to follow.The plot, backdrop, music and talent were all top notch. It was great that you used so many African-American artists to tell the tale of the black cowboy. It was also good to see Billy Zane in this movie. Does he ever play a good guy?I would highly recommend this film to anyone who wants to broaden their way of thinking. This is an excellent movie and I feel privileged to have seen it.

It came before "the ten commandments" "land of the Pharaohs" "Ben Hur" and it's overlooked today.How unfair!Based on Mika Waltari's mammoth novel ,it doesn't cheapen it!Waltari's novel was so huge only a miniseries could have done it justice (I hope it will be done some day).Waltari,whose message is essentially Christian remains intact(another of his books "the secret of the kingdom" (first part) takes place after Christ's death in the Holy Land).

The best bit in the film was when Alan pulled down her knickers and ran the cut throat razor over her bum cheeks and around her bum hole. It was also brilliant to see Alan's bum going up and down like a fiddler's elbow later on in the film.Alan was tough as hell in it like when he got annoyed and pushed the four eyed wimp onto the sofa.I've been laughing for days about the cut throat razor bit. A brilliant idea by the script writers. Alan must be brought back into Eastenders so he can do the same to Peggy.Alan is back, and this time he's armed with a razor.

On their way to a country house to hear a new play being read a theatrical producer , his secretary , and a renowned playwright find themselves lost in the idyllic English countryside. With each bickering over the proper direction, tensions between the three simmer. As the daylight dwindles and tempers fray, an eerie encounter at an unexpected stop leads them to a welcoming yet quirky inn run by a peculiar host. Inside the rustic abode, they discover other artists seeking inspiration who, much like them, stumbled upon this cozy safe-haven away from the stressors of their chosen crafts.

Absolutely, I agree with my previous commentator in describing this as a riveting,fascinating and certainly beautiful film. It's not necessary to see all the episodes,since the first ones are the best,while the last ones are a-bit tiresome,but for any person who likes German's and their good-natured ways,all episodes are worth seeing.In typical german fashion, values are constantly questioned,even it's murderous Nazi past is confronted in the last episodes, the rich dialogues are particularly interesting. These episodes are recommended for anyone who is about to live or travel in Germany,preferably in original language!

I first saw this one afternoon in the 80 's on network T.V . I think I was like 9 or 10 years old at the time, and I instantly fell in love with this movie. The visual effects were amazing, especially considering the era it was produced in. The vibrant colors, detailed costumes, and intriguing set designs really captured my attention and sparked my imagination. As a child, the unique story captured my sense of adventure, making me wish that I too could embark on exciting journeys with the film's characters.

Just see it! It's a smart movie but too hard to understand the first time. See it more than once. Everything that is seen or heard on the screen is intentionally crafted to evoke a feeling, sensation or tone. The clarity of certain visuals and the crispness of certain sounds are deliberately contrasted with blurred images or pops, crackles, hisses and barely audible sounds. The structure is non-linear and cyclical. Motifs recur as time runs both clockwise and counterclockwise. Expectations regarding "plot" and character" are broken signaling a non-traditional use of film to tell a story that is both contemporary and as old as humanity.

During the War for Southern Independence , GENERAL SPANKY mobilizes his forces to defend the local women & children against the onslaught of the ruthless enemy troops. Under the fierce leadership of General Spanky, brave soldiers rally together and strategically engage the opposition, driven by their undying commitment to safeguard their homeland and loved ones. Throughout the bitter conflict, General Spanky proves himself as an innovative military strategist, displaying unwavering fortitude, relentless pursuit of victory, and an inspiring ability to unify those under his command. Resolutely, his courageous men form a formidable resistance and bravely confront their adversaries.

I saw this movie when it was first released and thoroughly enjoyed it. What a movie. I am in my 40s now and have 2 teenage kids and I would like them to see this movie. I would recommend it to anyone who loves a romance movie or older Elton John music.I have searched most of the stores that sell both new and old movies but have not come across any.I bought some old movies like " Melody" in Hong Kong, who had quite a collection of old movie, but they did not have this.

I first saw this on the big screen with my girlfriend . It was a fun romp with some cool action sequences and memorable characters that really had us entertained from beginning to end. The film's plot had us gripped with its blend of comedy, adventure, and unexpected twists, keeping us on the edge of our seats. The soundtrack perfectly accompanied the story, making the entire experience a great audio-visual delight. What made the night truly memorable, though, was sharing it with my girlfriend ‚Äì her laughter and enjoyment of the movie just made it that much more enjoyable.

Enjoyable film that gives you romance, women-on-the-verge psychodrama, work place sexual harassment, adultery, and fashion. It's all there. Typical characters found in corporate America. Joan Crawford is the usual long time employee bitch executive who feels the need to be such because she's with the big boys. Hope Lange is the entry level ambitious employee whose determined to get to the top by using her mind and not her body. Their personal lives is the subplot. Wardrobe for the film is great but someone forgot to tell Stephen Boyd's hairstylist that "a little dab will do ya!"

*spoiler* *spoilers* *spoilers* I found the film amusing.It was weird and I enjoy it,I laughed a lot so the bottom line is that I recommend the film.However I have problems with what LaBute wanted to say.The plot is very simple.Betty(Renee Zellweger), a hard life house wife watch her husband being murdered and while having forgotten everything she had seen,she follow her "true love" for a soap series character,Dr. David Ravell (Greg Kinnear). Simple enough but not enough to hold a 95 minutes film.

The Karen Carpenter Story shows a little more about singer Karen Carpenter's complex life. Though it fails in giving accurate facts, and details.Cynthia Gibb (portrays Karen) was not a fine election. She is a good actress , but plays a very naive and sort of dumb Karen Carpenter. I think that the role needed a stronger character. Someone with a stronger personality.Louise Fletcher role as Agnes Carpenter is terrific, she does a great job as Karen's mother.It has great songs, which could have been included in a soundtrack album.

`` The Honkers '' is probably Slim Pickens best performance of all time . When we were shooting , everyone on set could sense the magic happening. Slim effortlessly portrayed the complex character in a way that resonated with both the cast and the audience. His dedication to the role brought a level of depth and realism that truly brought the story to life. Throughout the film's production, it was evident that Slim's passion for his craft was infectious. It inspired not only his fellow actors but also the crew members to elevate their game.

The Ma & Pa Kettle characters were highly popular AND controversial. The films that featured their brood paved the way for television sitcoms that came after it and sought to emulate its winning formula. One obvious reference is 'The Beverly Hillbillies,' where the new home was bought with oil money, not having been won in a contest. You could even say the 1980s sitcom 'Newhart' borrows its idea of backwards rural characters from this series. Still, I wonder if Betty Macdonald, the Washington-based author who created these characters, didn't do more harm than good.

` 5 Years ago if you were to watch an Australian film you would expect to see crocodile hunters , kangaroo wranglers, and an outback setting steeped in Aboriginal folklore. These classic tropes created an exciting but rather one-dimensional view of the Australian culture and landscape. Fast forward to the present day and you will find that Australian cinema has matured significantly. The once predictable plots and character archetypes have given way to a wave of dynamic storytelling, delving deep into diverse social issues, personal struggles, and multiculturalism. Consequently, the Australian film industry now presents a rich and authentic exploration of contemporary life 'Down Under', attracting audiences worldwide.

`` Please , do n't kill me ! I 'm just an actor ! '' `` Can you play dead ? Because that's the role you've just been cast in," the cold voice replied menacingly. Trembling with fear, the actor desperately tried to recall his most convincing performance to-date. As he took a deep breath, he thought, maybe ‚Äì just maybe ‚Äì he could survive this ordeal. Silence filled the air before he fell to the ground with remarkable grace, his breaths shallow, heart pounding inside his motionless body.

After seeing Meredith in "Beyond the Prairie" I had to buy another film with her staring. I cannot believe how she let herself into this teenage flick. It's best to watch this one with the sound off but just concentrate on Meredith as she moves across the screen. Save your money until the TV network comes out with a DVD on "Beyond the Prairie". It's worth it at any price, this one needs to pay you to see. This pretty lady needs someone to put her into a script that can use both her talent as an actress and her beauty as a woman.

Both Jackie and Candice are terrific in this movie . They are well-suited to their roles and have several chances to showcase their talent and chemistry together. The emotional depth and complexity portrayed by these actresses makes the characters relatable, engaging the audience from start to finish. The witty banter and comical situations injected throughout the movie brings levity to the poignant story, offering the perfect blend of humor and heart. The strong supporting cast elevates the performances, making the movie a well-rounded ensemble piece. The phenomenal storytelling paired with Jackie and Candice's exceptional acting skills create a memorable, must-watch film.

Having just watched this with my mother (Who got it for Christmas) i was thrilled to find something different to the usual stuff i usually watch. All of the stories were detailed and you are able to feel strong emotion towards each character from the very beginning. Every storyline is followed through brilliantly, making you feel completely different things for every single character. The cast is amazing, my personal favourites being James Read and Lesley-Anne Down, as George Hazard and Madeline Fabray/LaMotte/Main. The whole thing is in depth and wonderful, making very compulsive viewing, i recommend it to almost everyone.

A remarkable film , bringing to the surface all sorts of feelings I had when I was much , much younger. The vivid portrayal of the characters not only transports you back to the naive world of innocence, but it also instills a strong sense of nostalgia. Masterful direction and poignant performances create an undeniable connection with the viewer, leaving one reminiscing on both the exhilaration and fragility of youth. Throughout this emotional journey, the movie skillfully highlights the value of genuine friendships and the internal growth stemming from personal experiences. A timeless work, it reignites the yearning to seize life and relive our lost moments of exuberance and abandon.

Wagon Master is a very unique film amongst John Ford's work. Mainly because it's the only one that is based on a story written by John Ford himself, the story that was elaborated by Frank Nugent and director's son ¬ñ Patrick Ford and turned into a screenplay, and because of director's personal opinion regarding it, Wagon Master is the film John Ford called the one which `came closest to being what I had wanted to achieve', to say so is not to say a little, but as Ford confessed once to Lindsay Anderson, his favourite was nonetheless My Darling Clementine and not any other.

This movie used to be played constantly on the Disney Channel when I was a bit younger , and I absolutely adored it! It was such a classic coming-of-age tale that expertly captured the magic and joy of youthful imagination. Disney Channel made a point to regularly air this enchanting feature, and for good reason. It had heartwarming friendships, suspenseful challenges, and that signature Disney magic. In addition, the young actors and actresses delivered powerful, yet relatable, performances that easily won over my childhood heart. All in all, I believe the movie evoked powerful feelings of nostalgia and remained an all-time favorite among young Disney Channel enthusiasts.

The first time I saw "Alice in Wonderland ¬ñ an X-rated Musical Comedy", was in the early '80 in a Movie-Theater in N.Y. City with some friends. I remember we actually enjoyed it very much, although we were left wondering why all the "goodies" were covered by in various forms shaped colored patches and why the movie was suddenly jumping from one scene to the next one, leaving us guessing...what we just missed. Obviously it was the soft-core edited (chopped) version, which left me with the desire to watch it again soon, but in its original integral version.

This Aussie flick filmed in 1999 does an OK job of portraying a bunch of small-time crooks in Kings Cross, Sydney. The plot focuses on the plight of a young would-be crim who's life is in danger after botching a job for his future boss. Very well acted by Heath Ledger and Bryan Brown. The plot is fairly believable with some very humorous moments in one scene which revolves around a bank heist. The setting-up of various themes central to the story is quite well done. Eg. When one crim is searching for bullets for his gun.

Daffy Duck has signs hanging from every inch of every available tree announcing that it 's rabbit season . But Bugs Bunny is not going to be an easy target. Determined to outwit Daffy, he switches the signs to read "duck season" and hides in his rabbit hole, leaving his feathery friend completely unaware. When Elmer Fudd shows up, gun in hand, he sees the signs and begins to target Daffy instead. A panicked Daffy must now work with his would-be nemesis, Bugs Bunny, to convince the overzealous Elmer Fudd that they have both made a mistake.

I did n't personally know Karen Carpenter , nor , Richard for that matter , so I must go by what I've read, watched, and heard about them through various interviews and documentaries. It is said that the Carpenters were incredibly talented musicians and a force to be reckoned with in the music industry during the 1970s. Karen, with her hauntingly beautiful voice, and Richard with his prowess in songwriting and arrangement, created timeless melodies that resonated with fans across the globe. Their story is as heart-wrenching as it is inspiring. They navigated fame together, experiencing both highs and lows as siblings and performers.

This twisted comedy is well acted and directed. Very funny and the production quality is outstanding. It is easy to see why this short film has been accepted into so many festivals and won awards.Everyone can identify with Calvin having a bad day, bad week, bad life. Travis Davis plays the role superbly! Richard Moll as Tim brings darkness and foreboding that gives this film just the right twistedness. The old man adds to the humor of the story. And who wouldn't love the suicidal goldfish!This short will bring lots of laughs.

In dramatising Wilde's novel, John Osborne has condensed events, eliminated a number of characters, and generally implied rather than shown Dorian's essential wickedness. If you want a more explicit rendering, see the 1945 film. Wilde and Robert Louis Stevenson lived in about the same time frame, but were certainly vastly different men and writers. This story really treats of a theme similar to Stevenson's "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde", but note that Wilde chose to treat his story as fantasy, whereas RLS took the scientific route.

I played Sam (the porter, Lou's sidekick) in the Film "Dead Rail" Which later aired as "Alien Express." And, I have to say that for my part I thoroughly enjoyed watching this film. As a struggling actor this was a chance for me to work with fantastic people, it gave me great scenes to include on my reel, and it allowed me to work on a dream job for a month and a half (no waiting tables!) Turi(the director) And Steve and Scott (the producers) Were very kind by giving me this opportunity to participate in the production.

I watched this movie at the first showing available in my area , and it was quite clear that most people in the audience were excited to see it as well. From the moment the film started, it captured my attention and took me on an unforgettable journey. The visuals were stunning and the performances by the actors were exceptional. The storyline had the perfect blend of action, drama, and suspense which kept me at the edge of my seat. This movie far exceeded my expectations and is a must-see for all.

Loved the shots of airports -- Dallas, Phoenix, Fresno, etc., just single buildings with the name in block letters on the roof. And the tri-motors, and the well-dressed passengers. Fast-forward 75 years....But what really got to me was the hammer and sickle emblem and what appeared to be a Chinese ideogram adjacent the logo, aft of the pilot's seat on the starboard side of the fuselage. Remember when the mutual acquaintance Neil and Jill encounter says that Jim'd become a general in a Chinese rebel army?

Robin Hood: Men in Tights (1993) was a much needed parody from Mel Brooks. He has the assignment of spoofing the Robin Hood legacy and the couple of movie dealing with the mythical honorable thief of English folklore. Cary Elwes stars as Robin Hood. He's looking for a few good men who'll join him in his quest to topple the evil sheriff of Nottingham (Roger Rees) and win the fair hand of Maid Marian. Robin also has to deal with Prince John (Richard Lewis).as well.

Once again Elmer is faced with the dilemma of who to shoot . Bugs of Daffy . He 's unsure of what to do, as his hunting instincts seem to conflict with the camaraderie he has formed with both Bugs and Daffy throughout their escapades. But he knows he must choose. As the sun sets on this particular day of toil and laughter, the consequences of Elmer's decision could echo in eternity, tearing at the very fabric of their legendary friendship. Amidst the bustling backdrop of nature's orchestra, Elmer braces himself and takes aim.

It 's funny because I read all the reviews on this page after getting this movie and it 's either a "love it" or "hate it" situation with no in-between. I decided to watch the movie and form my own opinion, and honestly, I can understand both sides of the argument. The storyline had a unique concept, which was great and refreshing, but at the same time, the plot was slightly chaotic and at times, it felt disconnected. The cinematography was outstanding and I really enjoyed the soundtrack as well.

Having just got the `` Loony Tunes Golden Collection '' ( which i HIGHLY recommend , by the way ) , I couldn't be more thrilled to revisit these classic cartoons from my childhood! This set contains six DVD discs with more than 50 of the best Loony Tunes episodes featuring all-time favorite characters, like Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Porky Pig, and Road Runner. Not only are the visuals remastered, but it also has bonus material, including commentary by animation experts and rare behind-the-scenes footage, which give fascinating insights into the creation of these beloved shorts.

Not knowing a great deal about the Truth and Reconciliation commission , I can only look at this as a general concept aimed at fostering peace and harmony within a nation or community. From what I gather, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission usually comes into play after a period of conflict, where atrocities have been committed and trust has broken down between different parties. It seems that the ultimate goal is to create an environment in which past grievances are aired and acknowledged in order to move forward with a more constructive and compassionate approach.

This was a pretty good episode . Though no `` Trapped in the Closet '' or `` Cartoon Wars , this episode still delivered its signature mix of satire, social commentary, and humor. The storyline had a surprisingly engaging balance, making even the simplest of scenes entertaining to watch. The episode tackled some serious contemporary issues, injecting just the right amount of absurdity and comedy without sacrificing depth. The colorful characters continued to engage the audience while driving the plot forward. The amusing narrative was not without unexpected twists, managing to keep fans engaged throughout the episode.

Don't watch this movie expecting the Jane Austen wit, crisp dialog or clever social commentary. This time around, the premise of Northanger Abbey has been updated in a very sensual way! In this version,Catherine's erotic daydreams are not just silly fantasies, but a connection to the world of adult sexuality she is just peeking into with her daylight adventures. By day she is very prim and demure, and her swain Henry treats her with the utmost courtesy. But as her own sexual nature awakens, her daydreams shift every so subtly from mild to steamy to lurid!

Very good `` Precoder '' starring Dick Barthelmess , which in a way , kind of reminded me of Hawks ' masterpiece "Only Angels Have Wings." The film follows Barthelmess as he plays the role of a brave yet weary pilot navigating the precarious skies to complete his missions. Just like the Hawks' film, "Precoder" wonderfully captures the true essence of adventure, determination, and camaraderie. Barthelmess' performance is undoubtedly impressive, managing to showcase the struggle his character goes through, and allowing viewers to immerse themselves into his turbulent journey.

Fata Morgana , the 1971 documentary-like film by German filmmaker extraordinaire Werner Herzog , filmed over several years in the Sahara Desert, delves deep into the intricacies of human existence and our relationship with nature. Straying from traditional narrative norms, this avant-garde cinematic masterpiece beautifully captures the hypnotic allure of desert mirages and the captivating spirit of its people. Herzog's contemplative gaze weaves poetic montages and landscapes, while blending observational footage with atmospheric scores, stirring poignant emotions in its audience. Evoking an array of interpretations, Fata Morgana unapologetically engages its viewers in a sensorial odyssey of philosophical introspection and redefining storytelling techniques.

First love . Teenage love . We all have experienced it even if it was not as sweet as the stories in books and movies often portray. Amidst the whirlwind of high school life and awkward adolescent feelings, those early romantic encounters served as a lesson in the world of love. Nervous giggles and stolen glances become a marker of this young love that starts growing between two inexperienced hearts. Tentative flirtations and awkward silences set the scene as both navigate their burgeoning feelings, unsure of what lies ahead. Palms sweating, faces blushing, stammered conversations; teenage love brings its own brand of bittersweet innocence.

I just saw this wonderfully filmed movie that captures the essence ofhigh-brow NYC, or any big city of mid-century America. The colors, thecars, the clothes and the coming of the Womens Movement. It reflects thecomf-cozy attitudes of relationships between men and women in thecorporate world. In some ways, things gave changed and in others, theyhaven't changed at all. Women still want what men have today, but theynow have all sorts of laws and equality mandates to get it for them. Inmy opinion, beautiful women will still THROW themselves at men inpursuit of thier goals!

I had always heard about this great mini-series , but viewed it for the first time this week , July 2021. The show definitely lived up to the hype, as the character development, storylines, and visuals were simply amazing. It is rare for a mini-series to have such an impact, keeping the audience fully immersed in every single moment. As an emotionally invested viewer, I could relate to the struggles of each character. Even though the show was from an earlier era, its themes are relevant even today. I was pleasantly surprised and I cannot recommend this hidden gem highly enough.

This show is really great. It's smart.It's funny.It's great acting and writing. This show is really the fastest show I've ever seen. The Dialogues are really funny and well acted. Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel have a great chemistry.You really do believe they are mother and daughter. This show really showed that mother daughter relationships really don't have to be just mother and daughter, they can be best friends but on the same time it shows that it's really hard sometimes being more than just mother and daughter especially with Lorelai and Emily.

Once again Elmer is faced with the dilemma of who to shoot. Bugs of Daffy. He's unsure of what season it is and Bunny and Duck arguing help matters not. Though Bugs proves he's the smartest once more by repeatedly using reverse psychology on Daffy in increasingly subtle ways. And when that runs out he does his trademark cross-dressing thingy. Daffy freaks out and demands the bunny be shot. Though Elmer is too stupid he is hopelessly in love with the girl bunny thing. Elmer really is to blame for all this.

So we saw this on DVD at our apartment here in Paris . We 're all here on an exchange program for a few months and movie nights have become a weekly ritual for us. Our cozy gatherings help us unwind and bond after exploring the city during the day. We had picked a classic French movie, hoping to improve our language skills and immerse ourselves in the local culture. Settling in with popcorn, blankets, and a charcuterie board, we enjoyed the film and noticed similarities in themes and character types with our own cinema experiences.

"The Honkers" is probably Slim Pickens best performance of all time. When we were shooting, everyone connected with the production figured that Slim was Academy Award material. Unfortunately, United Artists had a James Bond picture in release at the same time and did not devote much attention to "The Honkers". I personally feel this film was under-rated by most critics. Sam Peckinpaw's "Junior Bonner" was out at the same time and seemed to impress the critics more than our film. Also, Cliff Robertson had a rodeo film out a few months before our release and that might have hurt us, too.

Honestly , when I went to see this movie at the Rave theater in Plainfield Indiana , I did not have high expectations. The trailers looked average and it seemed like it might be just another clich√© film. However, I was blown away by the captivating plot and superb acting. The director and actors managed to tell a truly immersive and emotionally driven story that transcended the limitations of its genre. It wasn't only visually stunning, but it was also deeply engaging, as it challenged societal norms and allowed the viewer to become lost in this extraordinary world.

I only gave this nine stars instead of ten because i really do n't approve of pornography all that much , although I recognize that it is a matter of personal choice and preference. To be fair, the quality and execution of the content in this instance were commendable and the performers were professional. Moreover, the approach seemed more focused on consent, mutual pleasure, and responsible intimacy rather than a shallow or exploitative narrative. Nevertheless, as someone who is not particularly fond of adult entertainment, my bias might limit my ability to fully appreciate and rate it with a perfect ten stars.

Central Airport is the story of a pilot named Jim (Richard Barthelmess) who has one bad flight in over 4000 hours and is forced to give up commercial flying. He meets a beautiful girl named Jill (Sally Eilers) and the two start up an act involving flying and stunts.
