The two start a relationship, but when Jim is hurt, his brother (Tom Brown) takes over the act for a while and falls for his brother's girlfriend. From there, things get exciting and terribly terribly sad.This film is a pre-code because of several reasons.

Tex Avery 's tenure as director of cartoons for MGM was in the 1940s and 50s was one of the most innovative and influential periods in animation history. Known for his daring humor, eye-popping visuals, and sharp wit, Avery pushed the boundaries of the medium, leading to the creation of some of the most iconic characters, such as Droopy Dog and the wolf from "Red Hot Riding Hood." His unique storytelling and distinctive animation style transformed the entire industry and paved the way for future animators like Chuck Jones and Walt Disney.

My wife and I saw this when we were 17. The only good thing my father ever did (get us in). This is "our movie" and the music is "our songs". Michelle's song is "our" song. Yeah, nowadays, it's a crime to show naked children on the screen, but we were screwing at 16, why not these kids? The movie is- rich boy impregnates poor girl, then rich dad steals him away from her at the end, after she gives birth under impoverished conditions. She is left alone with child.

when the gilmore girls started in Germany i did not want to watch them because for me it was just something which was not unique. it was a series and i even did not know someone in it. later on, i realized that edward hermann is part of the cast of overboard (a movie, i absolutely adore). i had to watch it once with a friend and never stopped since. it's just fun. you have the feeling that it is okay to have sex before being married and it's okay to be a coffee junkie and to eat unhealthy stuff all the time.

One of the biggest French success of the year 2002 , `` l'auberge espagnole '' was also very well greeted abroad, gaining international recognition and popularity. This cultural phenomenon, directed by C√©dric Klapisch, explores the vibrant and chaotic life of a group of diverse European students living together in an apartment in Barcelona, Spain. Through humorous anecdotes and genuine interactions, "L'auberge Espagnole" beautifully showcases the multicultural mosaic of Europe and embodies the spirit of the Erasmus exchange program. As a witty, feel-good comedy that transcends language barriers, the film truly resonated with viewers and ultimately cemented its position as an iconic piece of contemporary French cinema.

Based on Mika Waltari's Book,This Second CinemaScope movie ever made is full of rich color,beautiful music and panoramic spectacle.The Plot sometimes gets muddled in contrite wording,But all in all it has a strong social content:Man is ruled by his emotions,and that every action has an equal consequence.But to truly enjoy this film,First see the movie,then read the book.Although different,it sheds light on a whole lot of things that were not seen on the screen,and gives breath to some more of the depth of Sinuhe.

It would be something to try and tell someone what Fata Morgana is very simply about. Or, maybe it isn't: Herzog goes to the Sahara desert and nearby villages to film assorted landscapes and the locals. But this is just the broadest stroke. It's a feat that you either surrender yourself to, or you don't. He gets into the form of the world around him entirely, without a story, bound only to certain aspects of written poetry, as his camera (shooting on supposedly discarded film stock) wanders like in a pure travelogue.

I 'm certain that people from USA do n't know anything about the rest of the world , but I must say this assumption is quite unfair and rooted in stereotypes. While it may be true that some individuals may lack global awareness, we should not generalize an entire population. In reality, there are numerous well-informed Americans who have an extensive understanding of different cultures, geopolitics, and global issues. The presence of world-renowned universities and organizations, multicultural cities, and access to the internet make it possible for citizens to broaden their understanding of international matters.

The entire series, not just The Blue Planet, is nothing short of amazing. The best nature series we have ever seen. The episode on the deep is like traveling to outer space! We have watched this with our 10 and 7 year old boys and all four of us have not been able to pull away. We read a negative comment on this and could not believe it. There is so much new information that we never learned in school. Its also the best view we have seen from any television or movie into the delicate balance of our earth's eco-system.

If there's one cartoon that helped to put UPA on the map more than any other, It's Gerald McBoing-Boing. This tale of a little boy who only speaks in sound effects has kept its charm for the last 57 years. Besides the effects, loved the music, the abstract animation and backgrounds, the narration by Marvin Miller, pretty much everything. And it won the Oscar for Best Animated Short of 1950. Glad to have seen it on YouTube after reading about this Dr. Seuss story for so many years. And Rocky and Bullwinkle creator Bill Scott also contributed, how awesome!

Absolutely , I agree with my previous commentator in describing this as a riveting , fascinating and certainly beautiful film that has managed to capture the hearts and minds of audiences worldwide. The impeccable direction, combined with a compelling and multi-layered narrative, effortlessly draws us into the story, making us feel as though we're right alongside the characters as they embark on their journey. Furthermore, the stunning visuals and remarkable performances have elevated this film into an instant classic. Its ability to blend powerful emotions and thought-provoking themes resonates deeply, leaving an indelible mark on those fortunate enough to experience it.

`` The Cell '' is a rather difficult film to classify . If you read the plot outline , `` The Cell'' seems like a straightforward psychological thriller. However, this unique cinematic experience goes beyond genres and immerses the audience into a dark, visually captivating world. Directed by Tarsem Singh, the film stars Jennifer Lopez as a child psychologist tasked with delving into the twisted psyche of a comatose serial killer, played by Vincent D'Onofrio, to save his latest victim. It blends elements of science fiction, horror, and drama in an engrossing storyline that explores the human mind's depths.

The Karen Carpenter Story shows a little more about singer Karen Carpenter 's complex life . Though it fails in delving deep into the intricacies of her personal struggles and relationships, it still provides a fascinating glimpse into her remarkable career and untimely death. Touching upon her battle with anorexia, the impact of her parents' expectations, and her strained bond with her brother Richard, the film sheds light on Karen's vulnerability behind her remarkable talent. Despite certain narrative shortcomings, The Karen Carpenter Story succeeds in celebrating the enduring legacy and angelic voice of one of the most influential singers of her time.

After `` Attack of the Fifty Foot Woman '' with Alison Hayes opened the doors for women to be just as intimidating as men in movies, the landscape of the film industry started to change dramatically. Gone were the days where females played a secondary or subordinate role, and women were suddenly cast as main characters in powerful and groundbreaking movies that celebrated the many dimensions of being a woman. Feminist and action flicks portrayed them as cunning warriors, unafraid leaders, resilient survivors, and fearless crusaders, all while dismantling long-standing patriarchal standards of gender representation in cinema.

I was expecting this movie to suck , but what I got was a pretty good slasher/gore film . Most of the kills were quite creative and brutal, satisfying even the most seasoned horror fans. The acting was surprisingly solid, making me care about the characters' fates, while the suspense had me on the edge of my seat. The storyline had some originality and refreshing twists, preventing the usual predictability. Although some cliche elements were present, they didn't feel overdone or tiresome. All in all, this slasher/gore film exceeded expectations, proving to be an enjoyable, adrenaline-pumping experience that breathes new life into the genre.

Im a die hard Dads Army fan and nothing will ever change that . I got all the tapes , DVDs, and even rare collectibles from the series. Watching Dad's Army has always been my favorite pastime, allowing me to escape to a different era, filled with hilarity and camaraderie. Whenever I hear the famous catchphrases like, "Don't panic!" or "Stupid boy! ", it just warms my heart and brings a huge smile to my face. I even find myself participating in fan forums and discussions about the show to connect with fellow enthusiasts.

I have n't seen this movie since it came out at a drive in theater , and I have been wanting to watch it again for nostalgia's sake. Recently, I came across the film online, and it instantly took me back to those golden days of watching movies under the stars with friends and family. As I began streaming it, the sense of excitement from years ago came flooding back. The film's story, acting, and cinematography were just as good as I remembered, and despite the advances in modern filmmaking, it still holds up today.

when I first heard about this movie, I noticed it was one of the most controversial films of the 1970s. I noticed the music was by Elton John, so I figured I had nothing to loose, so I got it. What a Surprise!!! The movie was awesome. It was true love is all about. The characters (Paul and Michelle) had no luxuries, no money, and sometimes no food, yet they were still happy. I recommended this film to all my friends, but they all critized my tastes, and even called me names, becuase the movie featured two minors naked.

Gregory Peck and Gig Young are competing for the same girl and after Peck sends Young on a very dangerous mission, the latter unexpectedly returns alive. Young, being well aware of Peck's treacherous motives, keeps silent about his grueling ordeal while cleverly playing along. The girl, unaware of the intense rivalry, starts falling for Young due to his unmatched charisma and heroic disposition. The conflict between the two men starts spiraling out of control as jealousy fuels dirty tricks and perilous confrontations. As the stakes get higher, they both need to decide what lengths they will go to for the affection of their lady love.

This comment discusses "North and South Book I" dealing with 1842-1861 periodThe 19th century history of the USA is mostly identified by people with the Civil War (1861-1865). This is a reasonable opinion because that was Civil War which put the Union under the severe test; that was the Civil War which made Americans realize how precious it is to live in peace; finally, that was this period which at last brought the end to the shameful system of slavery. From the birth of motion pictures, there were people who adapted that time onto screen.

`` Two Hands '' is a good addition to the Australian Film Catalogue.It is that curious mix of real life drama and dark humor that characterizes the best of Australian cinema. The film skillfully blends intense moments of crime, action, and suspense with heartfelt emotion and an endearing human touch. Set amidst the gritty underworld of Sydney, it showcases captivating performances from its talented cast, especially the late Heath Ledger and a pre-Hollywood fame, Rose Byrne. Driven by an engaging story, unforgettable characters, and distinct Aussie slang, "Two Hands" offers a refreshing break from Hollywood blockbusters, and solidifies its status as an Australian cinematic treasure.

I absolutely fell in love with this girls. let me tell you something: I am from Romania and here is only the sixth series running bunt every other day that is on USA TV I check the internet and download it from there, so i am in line with the rest of the world. I can not believe how deep I am in this show. I become to know absolutely everything about them I looked on the internet what's Rory's car what are their middle names and stuff like that: Rory is also Leigh and Lorelay is Victoria.

Brian ( Wesley Eure ) works for a security firm owned by Mr. Norton ( Conrad Bain ) . The firm specializes in providing top-notch protection to high-profile clients, including politicians and celebrities. One day, Brian receives an assignment to protect the daughter of a prominent businessman, Laura ( Julie Adams ), who has been receiving anonymous threatening messages. Initially, Laura dismisses the threats and is reluctant to cooperate with Brian. As their time together progresses, Laura begins to see the importance of her safety, and Brian discovers that there's more to the case than initially meets the eye.

Just Before Dawn really surprised me when I saw it by being far less of a gruesome horror adventure than I had anticipated. Rather, it showcased a cleverly crafted story that revolved around psychological tensions and a battle for survival in the midst of an eerie wilderness setting. As the suspense built up throughout the film, I appreciated how the director carefully revealed each character's intentions, and created palpable suspense by tapping into the primal fears of isolation and vulnerability. There was a smattering of gory moments, but the core focus was truly on developing an atmosphere of dread and engaging character dynamics.

I really like this show. It has drama, romance, and comedy all rolled into one. I am 28 and I am a married mother, so I can identify both with Lorelei's and Rory's experiences in the show. I have been watching mostly the repeats on the Family Channel lately, so I am not up-to-date on what is going on now. I think females would like this show more than males, but I know some men out there would enjoy it! I really like that is an hour long and not a half hour, as th hour seems to fly by when I am watching it!

When I watch a short like Boy-Next-Door , I find myself with a kind of bittersweet feeling . On the one hand, it is refreshing to see such creative storytelling, exploring unique themes and human relationships in a poignant and captivating manner. But, on the other hand, it leaves me yearning for more. A well-crafted short film like Boy-Next-Door resonates deeply, leaving viewers to ruminate on the complexity of the characters and the universality of their experiences. Though it may be fleeting in length, its emotional impact is long-lasting, and ultimately leaves me craving additional storylines that build upon this exceptional groundwork.

I remember seeing this movie for the first time with a friend while on vacation in Anaheim , California in 2010. It was a beautiful, sunny afternoon, and we were enjoying a break from our hectic Disneyland adventures. As we stepped into the dim theater, the air conditioner gave us respite from the heat, and the aroma of fresh popcorn greeted us. The excitement in our eyes was tangible as we eagerly settled into our plush red seats. I remember vividly that as the movie began to roll, both our faces lit up with joy, bonding us over a cinematic experience we would never forget.

This story has held a special place in my heart for the last thirty-one years . As a boy , I would often listen to my grandfather narrate it, sitting by the fireplace, his eyes twinkling with excitement as the story unfolded. The characters came to life before me as I immersed myself in their magical world, brimming with adventure, camaraderie, and valuable life lessons. Years later, now as a father myself, I cherish the opportunity to share this tale with my own children, passing on the enchantment, love, and wisdom embedded within it.

Neil LaBute takes a dramatic turn from his first two films , In The Company of Men & Your Friends & Neighbors, with his third feature, "The Unexpected Journey". This intimate drama showcases LaBute's ability to delve deep into the human psyche and explore the complexities of emotions, relationships, and morality. Weaving together an ensemble cast of vivid characters, the story follows an estranged family as they embark on a road trip that forces them to confront their past, work through their differences, and ultimately find solace in their bond.

-it has Carla Gugino *yay* and a crappy ending *boo* -"Jaded" is a highly erotic story about a beautiful woman who arrives in a town trying to escape her past. Whiles there she meets up with two lesbians and after a couple of drinks the two decide to have some fun. But one of the girls takes things a bit too far and rapes her whiles the second girl holds her down. She is discovered on the beach where the incident happens the next day and is taken to a hospital.

Pat Conroy's autobiographical book "The Water Is Wide" proves to be something of a Southern "Up The Down Staircase", yet despite the teacher-going-against-the-odds formula, "Conrack" really does move the audience with each little breakthrough and creative flash. These students (uneducated black kids on an island off South Carolina) are actually shown learning, and their collective wide-eyed innocence is remarkably sweet. The one actual actress in the bunch (Tina Andrews, an amazing performer) plays the "tough nut" Conrack has to crack, and once she falls under his charms, it all seems a breeze.

I absolutely ADORED this movie as a child and still do as an adult . To say that is even an understatement! It brings a wave of nostalgia that can make anyone smile from ear to ear. The timeless story, the unforgettable characters, and the beautiful animation have stood the test of time, making it a cherished classic for generations to come. The inspiring themes of friendship, loyalty, and adventure evoke an unparalleled warmth and joy every time I watch it. The captivating songs still ring in my mind as I remember those wonderful moments shared with friends and family.

I watched this movie for the first time around 1990 as a young kid and it scared the Jesus out of me. I loved it so much and I was dying to get my hands on it.In 2002, I remembered that this movie existed but I had no idea what it was called, so, I went to the I Need To Know section on IMDb and explained what the movie was about and tried to get the name of it. Anyway, eventually someone on IMDb told me, so I researched and tried to buy the movie.

This movie was awesome , if you want a movie with non-stop puns and laughter then this is right for you. The hilarious dialogue and incredible comedic timing of the actors kept the audience constantly engaged and roaring with laughter throughout. The slapstick comedy, mixed with a touch of dark humor, and even some clever pop-culture references cater to different tastes and ensures that there's something for everyone to enjoy. Add to that a well-executed plot with the perfect amount of twists and turns that keeps you hooked till the end, this film makes for an outstanding choice when looking for a night of quality entertainment.

This show is my guilty pleasure all the way ! ! When I first tuned in to America 's Next Top Model, I didn't think I'd become so addicted to it. But I find myself eagerly waiting for each episode, excited to see the transformations, stunning photoshoots, and fierce runway walks these contestants bring every week. It's amazing to watch the models evolve throughout the competition, growing both in their skills and confidence, even when drama arises in the model house. The judges, though brutally honest at times, genuinely want to mentor and prepare the models for the cut-throat world of the fashion industry.

Clich√©-avoidance is one of this film's main achievements. When you hear a vague outline of the story ¬ñ Erasmus students of mixed nationalities sharing a flat in Barcelona ¬ñ you predict a collection of Euro-stereotypes in a farcical tangle. Pas du tout! In fact, it's a finely judged comedy about a young Frenchman, Xavier, trying to make sense of human relationships. There are some excellently observed minor roles (the arrogant French neurologist, the insufferably irrepressible brother of the English girl, Xavier's forlorn mother) and some fine visual humour, especially in the opening scenes mocking the bureacratic complexity of the application procedure.

Please be aware that this film has nothing to do with the Radio City Music Hall ! As an archivist , I wanted to clarify this misconception before delving into the contents of the film. This movie is, in fact, an exploration of the fascinating history and cultural impact of radio as a medium of communication, set against the backdrop of various urban cities. As you journey through the vivid narratives of radio personalities and historical events, this documentary seamlessly intertwines captivating stories with archival footage. Undoubtedly, this compelling account delves into a completely different world from the one you might have expected.

An stunning look at the ocean and the life in it.The Good : The camera work was absolutely phenomenal . The breathtaking footage captures the vivid, enchanting beauty of marine creatures and their mysterious underwater world like never before. Vibrant colors, intricate details, and graceful movement create an immersive experience, leaving viewers mesmerized. Narration complements the visuals, effectively blending education with wonder. Various underwater ecosystems, including vibrant coral reefs and deep, enigmatic trenches, were meticulously explored, resulting in an engaging exploration of both the astonishing biodiversity of aquatic life and the harsh challenges faced in a changing global climate.

This film is remarkable in how unremarkable it is . This is the true story of one woman and one man who, against all odds, come together to find solace and inspiration in one another's lives. They traverse the complexities of societal expectations, personal obstacles, and emotional setbacks while bravely journeying towards the pursuit of their dreams. Set against the mundane yet nostalgic backdrop of suburban America, this film humanizes both characters, effortlessly blending vulnerability with resilience. The delicate interweaving of each subplot gracefully elevates the significance of simple human connection.

I think that Mario Van Peebles movie Posse is a very important film. It is an excellent entry point film to a side of history many are not aware of. This is a story of early black settlers, cow boys and infantrymen returning from the Spanish-American War with a cache of gold. The main character Peebles is haunted by memories of his murdered father. The racism applied to the new black settlers and infantryman is explored in this film with excellent casting including Melvin Van Peebles (Marios father), Billy Zane, Stephen Baldwin and a wonderful performance by Big Daddy Kane.

It's hard to know what to make of this weird little Aussie crime flick - on the one hand, it's an enjoyable little film with a great sense of humour; but on the other, it just lacks a certain something that ensures the film never reaches above it's boundary that keeps it trapped within the merely 'interesting' territory. That being said, Two Hands is a well plotted film that excellently juggles several stories at the same time, which allows several small climaxes throughout the movie, and that in turn helps to stop the film becoming boring.

I have not seen a better comedy than the King of Queens for many years . I rate it one of the best sitcoms ever created, both in terms of its humor and its relatability. Kevin James and Leah Remini have unbeatable on-screen chemistry that captivates the audience with every episode. Their portrayal of Doug and Carrie Heffernan perfectly embodies the trials, tribulations, and joys of a typical working-class American family, making viewers laugh out loud as well as genuinely care for the characters. Furthermore, the unique blend of quick-witted dialogue, clever storylines, and outstanding ensemble cast ensures that this show will continue to entertain for generations to come.

America 's Next Top Model is a great reality show in every sense . It has a great hostess , Tyra Banks, who brings charisma and expertise to the show. The series not only entertains millions of viewers but also showcases the exciting world of fashion, make-up, and photography. Contestants face fierce competition, and the show is packed with drama, tears, and victories, making it an engaging watch. Each season presents different themes, judges, and models, constantly evolving to remain relevant in the ever-changing landscape of modeling.

This movie is VERY LONG , but totally worth splitting up over several nights . It has an all-star cast including some of Hollywood's biggest names, who deliver exceptional performances throughout. The cinematography and visuals are stunning, drawing you into a captivating narrative. Moreover, the excellent soundtrack sets the tone for an epic journey full of twists, turns, and memorable moments. While the lengthy runtime may seem daunting at first, the sheer scale and depth of the storyline makes every minute worth it. Don't be discouraged by the duration; sit back, relax, and immerse yourself in this cinematic masterpiece that unfolds over multiple evenings.

My girlfriend and I saw this movie when it was originally released . The controversy that surrounded the original release of the film piqued our interest and we just had to see it for ourselves. The theater was packed, and you could feel the anticipation in the air. As the movie began, the controversy faded away and was replaced by awe at the impressive performances and intricate storyline. There was no denying the sheer brilliance of the cinematography and gripping dialogues. Once the movie was over, people stayed behind to discuss and debate their opinions.

Successful films on metaphysical subjects are rare , but Fata Morgana is a good case . You can chalk up its success to a captivating storyline and strong visuals that explore themes like existentialism, creation, and the meaning of life. This mesmerizing piece of cinematic art entices its audience with thought-provoking questions and mesmerizing landscapes, leaving a lasting impression on their minds. Fata Morgana, as a unique entry in the metaphysical genre, presents its viewers with intricate narrative layers while maintaining an air of mystery. This elevates the movie-watching experience, solidifying its position as an exception in the often overlooked, yet intriguing, world of metaphysical cinema.

I lack cable-vision and no longer have `` DirecTV '' . So being a rural resident I have to wait for shows and movies to be available on streaming platforms or resort to using an old-fashioned antenna. Living in a rural area can be frustrating at times when it comes to access to certain types of entertainment, but it also has its own set of unique charms. Limited access encourages me to explore the world outside of television, indulge in reading or spend time connecting with nature. On the other hand, it fosters my anticipation for when my favorite shows do become available online, giving me something to look forward to.

Renee Zellweger absolutely shines as Nurse Betty, easily one of the most charming, off-beat, and lighthearted comedies of the year.When soap opera obsessed waitress Betty Sizemore witnesses her insensitive husband's murder by two hitmen (Morgan Freeman and Chris Rock), she snaps and thinks the cast members on A Reason to Love are real. She decides to travel to Los Angeles to find famed heart specialist Dr. David Ravell (a character on the show).As the two oddly paired Hitmen, the caustic Rock and the pontificating Freeman generate some very fun chemistry, and Greg Kinnear also has fun with his smarmy offscreen actor persona.

I do n't usually like to see movies while they 're still in theaters because of high ticket prices but last weekend, I decided to treat myself. I went to see the highly acclaimed movie that had just been released. I have to admit, there was something magical about being among the first people to witness it on the big screen. The crowd's energy, reactions, and emotions truly amplified the entire cinematic experience. In the end, despite the expensive ticket, I left the theater feeling thoroughly entertained and surprisingly grateful for the unique atmosphere.

Sure, it has its pretentious moments, it plays like art-house, live-action Fantasia, but it also has moments of deep beauty and humor. Omnibus films are always a problem, but I have always had a keen interest in them. I will now rate the segments individually.Nicolas Roeg - "Un ballo in maschera" - This segment may very well spoil the film for some people, because it is absolutely the worst of the whole bunch. It is difficult to follow, mostly because it tries to adhere to a clear plot (a hackneyed one, at that).

Inarguably one of the most interesting filmmakers of the last 50 years, Werner Herzog has been pushing the boundaries of cinema perhaps more so than any other commercial filmmaker. I've been acquainted with Herzog for a few decades now and I've never not been impressed by both the man and his work. Last year I went to see Rescue Dawn and was somewhat surprised at how relatively mainstream the film was, yet couldn't help but imagine Herzog taking his actors and crew into the actual jungle to not only make the film, but to live it.

Thank you Mario Van Peebles for informing us of not only the existence of black cowboys , but providing a fascinating glimpse into their rich history and culture through your work. The untold stories of these resilient individuals, who were such integral parts of the American frontier and its expansion, offer important perspectives in our collective understanding of the past. Your effort in showcasing their skill, courage, and ingenuity has broadened the representation of cowboys and the Wild West. By shining a light on these historically overlooked trailblazers, you have given a voice to a proud legacy, paving the way for future generations to be inspired by their accomplishments.

The Truth and Reconciliation process in South Africa is a vital and probably unique human experiment. This movie does an excellent job of revealing the complexity of the task and the incredible challenges facing South Africa. I believe every one should see this movie as I think few people outside of South Africa understand its past and what is being attempted in the Truth and Reconciliation process. Almost every country has some part of its own history which is still a source of continuing hatred and bitterness. We all need to understand ways of dealing with the past. What's happening in South Africa should guide us all.

I too saw this movie when it first came out. I was a teenager at the time, and I saw it with my girl friend who later became my wife. I remember the movie made me feel it was possible to beat the odds. The cinematography was very well done if memory serves me correctly. The boy was a little much, but the girl character was very interesting. I thought it was very romantic and that might have been the intro to the first time with my then girlfriend. I have not seen the movie since and I wander why it has gone to the wayside.

I love to see a female protagonist , in this movie her name was Rose . Rose brought out a sense of power and resilience that we often lack in traditional on-screen depictions of women. Her character was multidimensional and brilliantly acted. Not only was she fierce and confident, but she was also compassionate, empathetic, and driven by purpose. In the face of challenges, she stayed true to herself and continued fighting for what she believed in. Through the movie's ups and downs, she remained a source of strength and determination.

This film is remarkable in how unremarkable it is. This is the true story of one woman and one man and their quest for happiness amid the dull, rote life of a housewife and "man of the house". It could be any couple, any family, in any town... but that's what makes the story so moving. It touches each of us in some way and reminds us of someone we know and love, or of ourselves. I laughed, I cried, I couldn't stop thinking about it... and what more could you ask for from a film, really?

Pat Conroy 's autobiographical book `` The Water Is Wide '' proves to be something of a Southern `` Up the Down Staircase '' with its recount of a young, idealistic teacher's struggles to make a difference in an impoverished South Carolina island school in the late 1960s. Pat uses this backdrop to illustrate the appalling disparity in educational resources between rural black students and their white counterparts. As he engages with his students, community and oppressive school officials, the narrative unfurls with deep themes of prejudice, political struggles, and the essence of human relationships.

This game is very good for the n64. You can skate as Tony Hawk, Bob Burnquist, Steve Caballero, Kareem Campell, Eric Koston, Bucky Lasek, Rune Glifberg, Andrew Reynolds, Elissa Steamer, Jamie Thomas, Rodney Mullen, Chad Muska, and maybe some more skaters. The game doesn't have Mike V or Bam Margera. Dang! Well anyway, the gameplay is awesome. The level School II is a great level with so much to skate. In Career mode, you collect SKATE, get money, get high scores and other various things in 2 minutes.

I have remembered this cartoon for over 50 years - what staying power it has! It was funny and creative; I wish my children and grandchildren could have seen it. It ranks right up there with Winky Dink - another favorite. I was pleased to find out that one of the creators later worked on Rocky and Bullwinkle. These early shows had a lot going for them that todays cartoons for kids don't have. Today's cartoons seem to push the idea that one needs something special, some magic formula or talent to be able to succeed against evil or dangerous circumstances.

I finally received my DVD today, viewed it and I'm pleased to announce this is the original theatrical version of the film. As you may have read in previous reviews of "Rich and Famous" that the edited for TV version of the film that somehow made it onto VHS sometime in the late 90's but, now WB has corrected the error and released it on DVD complete with the airplane restroom scene, Matt Lattanzi's bare butt, and the scene in the Hotel room where Liz (Jacqueline Bisset) calls Merry (Candice Bergen) a C**t!

Inarguably one of the most interesting filmmakers of the last 50 years , Werner Herzog has been pushing the boundaries of cinema and challenging audiences with his thought-provoking stories and eccentric characters. Since the late 1960s, his diverse filmography has encompassed both documentaries and fiction, defying conventional genre norms and reflecting Herzog's singular vision. Beyond simply entertaining, Herzog's films often delve deep into human psyche, exploring themes of obsession, ambition, and isolation. Driven by the auteur's bold narrative and unique perspective, his works redefine cinema, reshaping perspectives on what it can and should be.

Robert Altman , Nicolas Roeg , John-Luc Goddard -- you were expecting a fun film the entire family could enjoy together, perhaps? Unfortunately, these celebrated directors are known for their boundary-pushing, avant-garde films that cater to more mature and artsy audiences rather than to kids with short attention spans. Think mysterious, intense storylines riddled with twists, mind-bending surrealism, and dialogue exploring profound existential themes. While these may offer a cinematic feast for enthusiasts of independent films, these auteurs‚Äô darkly provoking masterpieces could leave younger audiences scratching their heads and craving a quick fix of laughter and adventure, as opposed to delving into enigmatic characters and adult complexities.

In Crystal City , a group of Mormons hire the horse traders Travis ( Ben Johnson ) and Sandy ( Harry Carey Jr.) to guide them safely across the wild frontier to a promising plot of land in the San Juan Valley. As the journey commences, both men, accustomed to a life of isolation and tough encounters, learn about the core values of faith, love, and camaraderie as the convoy encounters challenges of the unpredictable, unforgiving land. Bandits, grueling conditions, and divided leadership lead Travis and Sandy to reconsider their initial understanding of what makes a person truly tough.

I think that Mario Van Peebles movie Posse is a very important film . It is an excellent entry point into the discussion of race, identity, and power in the American West. Set in the late 19th century, Posse offers a perspective that showcases the experience of African American cowboys and how they battled racial oppression during that time. Featuring a predominantly black cast, the movie empowers and celebrates people of color and their unique contributions to Western society. Besides highlighting the contributions of Black cowboys, it also draws attention to the resilience, courage, and strength of these individuals.

"L'Auberge Espagnole" collected the audience wherever it was shown. It gathered audience awards on many film festivals all over the world. And it is not strange. We have the ability to watch a cheerful and an astonishing piece of art. And it is wise by the way. "L'Auberge Espagnole" is a very funny comedy about youth and growing up. But most of all it is about the lights and shadows of living in the European Union.The main character of the film is a French student of economy Xavier. For his future carrier his is sent for one year of studying to Barcelona.

The tunes are the best aspect of this television film which has admittedly better-than-average production values , but very surface -level storytelling. With a catchy and memorable soundtrack, the television film manages to capture the viewers' attention and create an engaging experience. Visually, the scenes are well shot, and the costume and set designs are meticulously crafted, adding to the overall aesthetic appeal of the project. However, the film's weak point lies in its lack of depth and substance in terms of storytelling, leaving viewers unsatisfied and craving a richer narrative experience.

Kane is a killer named Jacob Goodnight, he lives in this burned down old hotel, where eight teen convicts go to do some cleaning. Most of them die except for 3 of them. In my case it wasn't the best writing or the best ever. I still thought that the killing scenes were really well done. Like when the one girl go eaten by the hungry dogs. The best had to be when he shoved the cell phone down the Blonde Girl's mouth. Kane was a seriously great horror movie actor, he had this serious look the entire movie and it would never change.

`` The Cell '' is an exotic masterpiece , a dizzying trip into not only the vast mind of a psychopath, but also into the mysterious realm of human consciousness itself. Director Tarsem Singh meticulously constructs a dark and nightmarish atmosphere, brimming with lavish imagery, bizarre dream sequences, and brilliantly unsettling character design. By breaking the barriers between reality and the subconscious mind, "The Cell" artfully unravels the human psyche in the most mesmerizing way, forcing its viewers to confront and challenge their perception of fear, fantasy, and sanity.

As Betty Sizemore (Renee Zellweger) secretly watches her tyrannical husband Del (Aaron Eckhart) being murdered by the vengeful hitmen Charlie and Wesley (Morgan Freeman and Chris Rock), her bruised sense of reality becomes totally immersed in the fantasy world of her favorite soap opera. In a state of complete denial and delusion, Betty escapes both physically and mentally from her unsatisfied, small town life to search for "Dr. David Ravell" (Greg Kinnear), the handsome and loving hero of "A Reason to Love", a soap opera set in a hospital and produced in Los Angeles.

After Mrs and Mr. Iyer this is yet another very good film by Aparna sen(mostly in English). In the earlier film she treated a contemporary political environment and its effect on individuals. In this film it is the impact of mentally disabled member of the family and its impact on the family. As a parallel sub theme she treats a philosophical concept on "reality". It is a film which leads to thinking after seeing the film.Mithee the younger sister (Konkana Sen Sharma, the daughter of Aparna Sen) is suffering from Schizophrenia being taken care of by the dominant elder sister Anjali (Shabana Azmi) .

I saw this film on the same night I saw 6 other shorts. This one was leaps and bounds ahead of the others in terms of quality of acting, directing, filming and originality of story. It comes together with a professionalism often lacking in short films.This is a great short film for the following reasons: 1. Amazing performances. The 2 actresses are both compelling and believable instantly. Their chemistry is palpable; the depth of their relationship is conveyed, even though the film is 10 mins long. The acting and directing are very powerful.2. Beautifully shot.

This probably ranks in my Top-5 list of the funniest movies I 've ever seen ! I was not a huge fan of slapstick comedy before watching this masterpiece, but it has completely changed my perspective on this genre. The impeccable timing, brilliant performances from the star-studded cast, and outstanding one-liners left me in tears, grasping my sides due to laughter. Moreover, the sheer unpredictability and countless twists and turns in the storyline are not only commendable but addictive, leaving you wondering what's going to happen next. Trust me when I say you will never have a dull moment when watching this flick.

This movie is VERY LONG, but totally worth splitting up over several nights. It has an all-star cast, and if you are a Patrick Swayze fan, this will get your heart to throbbing! :-) My mother is a Civil War buff, and a history teacher, and every summer we would watch this movie (we had recorded it off TV), over several, several nights until we got through the whole thing. We had every line in the movie memorized, lol. Pop some popcorn, sit back, and enjoy the action and romance.

I resisted watching 15 Park Avenue despite of recommendations, discarding the movie as a clich√©d topic of extreme emotional dramas and over-the-top acting.Once in a while, movies like 15 Park Avenue come by and sweep you off your feet.The movie grasps your attention pretty early on and there is no moment to rest after that. Aparna Sen has done a wonderful job of gluing the audience to every line of the movie. The impeccable character development, "just right" amount of emotions and an enigmatic end to match it all...I have a renewed respect for Konkana Sen Sharma, who convincingly plays the schizophrenic Mithi.

I 'm not the biggest fan of westerns . My two personal favorites though are Unforgiven , and Tombstone . However, there's something intriguing about westerns that often reels me in, despite my preference for other genres. The appeal could lie in the rugged, individualistic nature of these characters that were bred in the unforgiving, yet charming, Wild West. It might also have to do with the striking cinematography showcasing beautiful landscapes that so vividly illustrate the background for the vivid gun-slinging action, as witnessed in films such as Unforgiven and Tombstone.

Come on. Anyone who doesn't understand the greatness of this here cartoon should be kicked off any critic's panel. They should not be allowed to be heard, because they obviously have no sense of humor whatsoever. Anyone who does not love this here animated cartoon directed by Tex Avery should be chained to a chair and forced to watch "Huckleberry Hound" episodes for 20 years straight! The takes and double-takes by the Wolf in this cartoon are the finest examples of this important past of comedy that have ever been captured on film. Tex Avery should receive a posthumous Academy Award for this cartoon.

With all the dreck out there , this is a gentle movie about young love . Yes , it 's a bit cliche and predictable, but the sincere emotions and beautiful cinematography make it worth watching. The protagonists portray the innocence and intensity of first love, learning to navigate the complexities of relationships and adulthood. Along with the subtle humor, this coming-of-age tale touches the heart and ignites a feeling of nostalgia for one's own youthful romance. Through engaging dialogues and dynamic interactions, this story takes us back to the simplicity of those bygone days when every emotion felt like a magical adventure.

* spoiler * * spoilers * * spoilers * I found the film amusing.It was weird and I enjoy it . The quirky, offbeat nature of the movie definitely added an element of unpredictability which was quite refreshing, as it strayed from typical cliches found in many films today. The humor was witty and blended seamlessly into the surreal storyline, eliciting laughs throughout. The well-written characters further enhanced the experience with their captivating, oddball personalities. Overall, this unconventional film was thoroughly entertaining and would highly recommend it to anyone seeking a bizarre, fun-filled cinematic adventure.

I've been waiting almost 25 years to see this hard to find horror thriller and I finally did since it's proper rebirth on DVD. Of course it didn't have the same impact on me as it would have if I had seen in it the 80s, but director Lieberman (his film "Squirm" is excellent) makes good use of the lovely Oregon location and takes the time to develop the characters, not just to have them dispatched in creative ways. A high note, Brad Fiedel's whistling music is really creepy and adds to the desolate proceedings making this great fun for genre fans.

I watched this movie at the first showing available in my area, and it was quite clear that most people didn't get the movie. Even if you don't, it's a good movie with some interesting character development. It is a thoroughly human story about some very imperfect people in a backwoods southern town, and really speaks to the root of the blues. If you don't know what the "Black Snake Moan" is by the time you leave the theater, you didn't get it. And no.. it's not just a song.

15 Park Avenue , well the name mystifies initially being an address from New York and film being set in Kolkata, India. However, the intriguing title aptly captures the essence of the film. Directed by Aparna Sen, "15 Park Avenue" navigates the complex intersections between reality and delusions experienced by Mithi, a young woman grappling with schizophrenia. Shot on a quaint Kolkata backdrop, the storyline draws its audience in through heartwarming bonds shared amongst family members who endure the strenuous experience of living with a loved one afflicted with mental illness.

Surprising, witty, funny and totally engaging, the film grabs a little-known reality: that of the student that goes studying in an Erasmus program. The beginning is great, as the story kicks off, of course it has a few lulls on the midsection, and the story drifts sometimes away from the main character, but the viewer won't bother - the movie is young, fresh, and light-hearted, even though I don't agree with the notion that when you do Erasmus and you come back you no longer make part of that universe. But that's just me.

There 's a brand new killer on the loose , and he 's doing God 's work . Yeah right , that's what he thinks. This twisted maniac goes by the name of 'Divine Intervention.' Every gruesome crime scene has a different scripture painted in blood, calling out each of his victims as sinners and quoting their alleged transgressions. Detective Lawrence Montgomery has taken up the grisly challenge of chasing this self-proclaimed 'angel of vengeance.' Racing against time, the detective uncovers sinister secrets about his own past as he delves deeper into the depraved and calculating mind of the 'Divine Intervention' murderer.

After getting hooked on the mini series, "North & South," I could hardly wait for the continuation, "North & South II." Then years later, along came Book III, "HEAVEN & HELL - NORTH & SOUTH - BOOK III." FINALLY, the last installment came for the on-going saga of the Maine and Hazard families. I was so enraptured by this series that I taped each part off of TV and then managed to get family and friends hooked and I watched it AGAIN, each time someone new wanted to see them.

Pity the poor reviewer who disliked / didn't understand this wonderful film. What a sad life he must lead!This movie has more to say about life and relationships than most I've ever seen, yet it's not dark or preachy like the "ordinary people" type of film. It is mostly humorous, though not technically a comedy.The whole thing feels a little like a fantasy, perhaps Shakespear's "Midsummer Nights' Dream." Beautiful, intelligent women abound, with wonderful cinematography and a non-insulting screenplay that doesn't miss a beat.I look forward to seeing it every time this film is re-run on cable.

Great period piece that shows how attitudes have changed in 40 years. Great production design, appealing stars, great lines ("Miss Bender, I don't care if you beat it out on a native drum! ", says Joan Crawford's Amanda Farrow to Hope Lange when Lange incredulously asks how she is expected to read a summarize a large amount of manuscripts in a very short time). If you've seen this movie panned and scanned on TV and not in the letterboxed version on pay-TV or AMC (American Movie Classics) you haven't really seen it.

A couple of cowpokes help a group of Mormons cross some rough country on their way to a new settlement. This low-key Western is unusual for Ford in that it lacks any big stars. Johnson gets top-billing but his is basically a supporting role, although he and Carey work well together. Dru is given little to do other than provide the love interest. The best performance is given by Ford favorite Bond, playing the leader of the Mormons. In fact, this role helped him land a starring role in the long-running TV Western "Wagon Train" before his untimely death at age 57.

This is the best movie I have ever seen. It has it all tragedy and happiness love and hate. And a deep friendship that not even war can destroy.The most splendid casting I have ever seen. Patrick Swayze and James Read were top grade in this movie.If you see part 1 you will want to see it all. Some of my friends watched part of the movie at my home then went out and bought the movie.I am a civil war buff but this movie got my grandchildren interested in history. Any movie that can get children to learn history is great.

**SPOILERS AHEAD**It is really unfortunate that a movie so well produced turns out to besuch a disappointment. I thought this was full of (silly) clich√©s andthat it basically tried to hard. To the (American) guys out there: how many of you spend yourtime jumping on your girlfriend's bed and making monkeysounds? To the (married) girls: how many of you have suddenlygone from prudes to nymphos overnight--but not with yourhusband? To the French: would you really ask about someonebeing "√† la fac" when you know they don't speak French?

Just Before Dawn really surprised me when I saw it by being far less of a gruesome horror adventure than I expected. Instead the director Jeff Lieberman conjures up a wonderfully evocative and disquieting atmosphere for great stretches of the movie, building the suspense constantly until I was really unsure about what was going to happen but wound up tight as a spring waiting for it. The lack of action in many parts gave it a very Deliverance mixed with The Texas Chainsaw Massacre kinda ambiance, and when the action really kicks in, its truly shocking and dramatic, without ever even really needing to be gory.

Michelle , Anic√©e Alvina , was so nice , and I really fall in love with her . She died suddenly at the age of 58, leaving a huge void in my heart. The memories we shared, the laughter, and the moments spent together are all I have left to cling on to now. Michelle's vivacious personality, contagious laughter, and incredible heart had always managed to light up the room. Though it is immensely painful to have lost her so suddenly, I'm eternally grateful to have known such a remarkable person.

First of all - I'm not one to go all sappy over movies. I saw Friends in the 70's when it was first released. I was about 17 years old at the time. Even now, at age 50, I still can remember some of the scenes. The movie is sweet and sad and may actually be too tame for teenagers today but I loved it. The story is about innocence, the purity of young love and the determination of 2 young people to make a better life for themselves then they had at home.

`` Two Hands '' is an entertaining , funny story about Australian lowlifes . The screenplay contrasts the world of street crime and gritty realism with a surprising element of supernatural whimsy, drawing the audience into the absurdly twisted lives of its characters. Our protagonist, a small-time crook named Jimmy, suddenly finds himself at the center of an increasingly complicated series of schemes, all thanks to a seemingly innocuous visit to a fortune teller. With a chaotic blend of action, romance, and an ensemble of idiosyncratic misfits, this unpredictable tale delivers not only laughter and thrills, but also leaves viewers questioning the bizarre and unpredictable nature of life itself.

A good old-fashioned flight-and-revenge western , given a twist and a touch of gravitas by injecting a little black social history into the mix, creates a captivating fusion of genres. The protagonist embarks on a perilous quest across the lawless and rugged frontier, seeking vengeance for unspeakable acts inflicted upon him and his community. This character-driven narrative brings newfound depth and intensity to the timeless struggle of racial injustice, touching the viewers deeply with profound humanity amidst the bloody, bullet-riddled backdrop. Stirring themes of unity, resilience, and retribution imbue the story with an enthralling complexity, while ultimately exploring the raw duality of good versus evil.

Robin Hood; Men in Tights is worth watching, I recently watched it because I've just become a Cary Elwes fan, and this is one of of his lead-roles. Some moments really made me crack up so hard! I didn't expect them you know, it was so funny, Even the 2nd time around you'd still fall off your chair The cast is great, of course especially Robin of Locksley himself,Cary, but Blinkin and the Sheriff and Little John (Don't let the name fool you, it's veryy big!

when I first heard about this movie , I noticed it was one of the most controversial films of the year, garnering a range of reactions from people who loved its powerful storytelling to others who couldn't stomach the graphic content. I had to see it for myself to form my own opinion. After finally watching the movie, I found myself captivated by the masterful storytelling, poignant character arcs, and cinematography, yet utterly challenged and shaken by the stark depictions of violence, societal issues, and themes presented throughout the film.

I 'll be brief : I normally hate films like this venomously ... but there is just something about this particular movie that captivated me despite my initial misgivings. The cinematography, acting, and character development surpassed my expectations and managed to keep me hooked till the very end. Perhaps it was the witty script, the innovative plot twist, or the subtle touches of humor interjected throughout; whatever it was, it struck a chord that resonated deeply. While I still find this genre predominantly underwhelming, I am unexpectedly eager to recommend this refreshing take that surely deserves accolades for its well-executed blend of uniqueness and charm.

Hands down , the best drama/comedy show on television . A cleverly written show about a young mother and her teenage daughter, both navigating through life's ups and downs, challenges and successes. Set in a quaint small town filled with quirky, loveable characters who bring the perfect balance of heart and humor to the screen. This captivating, addictive series shines with impeccable acting, exploring family bonds, friendships and even romance with witty banter and impeccable comedic timing. Offering valuable life lessons with an excellent blend of dramatic tension and laugh-out-loud moments, it remains relevant and impactful for a new generation to rediscover its magic.

THE CELL ( 2000 ) Rating : 8/10The Cell , like Antz , must be watched twice to be appreciated fully. This visually stunning, surreal sci-fi thriller is a psychological roller coaster that explores the depths of a serial killer's mind. With Jennifer Lopez's solid performance and Tarsem Singh's unique direction, this film breaks conventional narrative barriers, showcasing impressive, evocative visuals that simultaneously enchant and disturb viewers. Although The Cell received mixed reviews, one cannot deny its cult-classic status. For viewers with an open mind and a taste for the extraordinary, the movie's beautiful artistic execution will be hard to forget.

If I 'd only seen the poster for Nurse Betty , I probably would n't have touched it with a ten-foot pole. The movie's advertisement featuring an all-star cast in awkward, goofy poses screamed 'trashy, cliche-filled flick,' but what a deception that was! Despite my initial reservations, I eventually gave it a chance and what unraveled on the screen was pure cinematic brilliance. Led by the superb performance of Ren√©e Zellweger, the plot artfully mingled quirky humor, heartwarming drama, and moments of gut-wrenching intensity, successfully overturning every trope you might've expected from such a poster.

Wagon Master ( 1950 ) Dir : John Ford Production : Argosy Pictures / RKO Radio Pictures John Ford brings his iconic vision of the American West to life in this classic film, Wagon Master (1950). In this Argosy Pictures/RKO Radio Pictures production, a group of Mormon pioneers embark on a challenging journey through the rugged Utah Territory in search of a place to call home. Leading the wagon train are horse traders, played by the talented Ben Johnson and Harry Carey Jr., who must guide these determined settlers safely across the untamed wilderness.

This movie is a piece of the time in which it was made ..... Realistic . Movies were not candy -coated or sugarcoated like they are today; they dealt with raw, harsh reality. The audience was eager for stories that felt authentic, relevant, and offered some depth of truth. Set in an era defined by complex political and social upheavals, the filmmakers portrayed characters fighting to survive in the face of systemic poverty, emotional hardships, and interpersonal conflicts. The lack of polish and artifice that may turn some away actually lends credibility to the film, connecting audiences with a meaningful story on a deeper, emotional level.

Guess a few upscale film directors were sitting around sipping their absinthe, grappa, aramangac or jungle juice some night in the 80's during the Cannes or other film festival and one said "Hey, guys let's do a movie where each of us creates a segment around a world class aria." Welllll...it kind of sort of worked. Clearly someone was smart enough to select some of the best recordings of the arias chosen, for example Bjoreling's Nessun Dorma, so if you were blind and lying on the floor just listening to the DVD you got more than your money's worth.

Working at a movie theater as a projectionist, I have the opportunity to watch basically every movie that comes out. When I first saw the trailer for 'Black Snake Moan' I laughed and thought, "Great. Another 'Snakes on a Plane' Samuel L Jackson movie". But of course, I wanted to see it for the laugh factor. Many people have judged this movie too quickly based on the innuendo in the title, the images on promotional ads and on the fact that Justin Timberlake is in the film. Personally I loved every second of this movie.

If there 's one cartoon that helped to put UPA on the map more than any other , It 's without a doubt "Gerald McBoing Boing." Created in 1950, this endearing character has remained etched in the memories of animation lovers everywhere. In the short films and TV series that followed, the charming boy, Gerald, captivated viewers with his unique form of communication ‚Äì speaking only in expressive sound effects, rather than actual words. Thanks to "Gerald McBoing Boing," UPA Studio pushed the boundaries of traditional animation, changing it forever.

See No Evil With Kane. The Movie Has a great storyline But it just wasn't a Hide my eye's, Scream Out Loud Horror Flick I thought it was going to be from watching the WWE Superstars on Monday Night Raw When The Movie First Came To Theaters. I Did ENJOY The Movie Though I Loved The Story It Played Out.GREAT MOVIE EXCELLENT WOULD LIKE TO SEE A PART 2 It Doesn't Matter If Kane Gets Killed At The EndOr Not They Have Killed Off Other Horror Stars In Every Movie They Have Out And They Still Comeback For More So a part 2 wouldBe Very Interesting.

Our America is multi-cultural , with so many sub-cultures . This movie simply tells a story of a snapshot in time of a specific community, highlighting the rich tapestry of cultural interactions within our diverse nation. In this tale, we follow various characters from different backgrounds and upbringings as they come together in a heartwarming, emotional journey. Through love, loss, laughter, and healing, these unique individuals remind us of our shared humanity despite the diversity in cultures. As the narrative unfolds, we're ultimately brought to a renewed understanding that embracing our individual differences is what truly unites us, making our America so beautifully interconnected.

Sure , it has its pretentious moments , it plays like art-house , live-action Fantasia , but it also has a depth and sincerity that is truly captivating. Visually stunning and thought-provoking, the film delves into complex themes, offering audiences a raw and emotional experience that is both exhilarating and discomforting. The narrative weaves seamlessly between the whimsical and the dark, keeping viewers enthralled in a mesmerizing dance of light and shadows. A compelling soundtrack complements the film's bold and inventive aesthetics, evoking a nostalgic yet poignant atmosphere that lingers in your mind long after the end credits roll.

I can barely even remember what DECADE I saw this film . It was when I was a teenager , which feels like ages ago. Anyway, it left a lasting impression on me, as it resonated with my adolescent curiosity and desire to explore life's complex themes. Set amidst an engaging plot, the powerful acting brought depth and humanity to each character. Now that time has passed, I feel like I should re-watch it and see if it still holds the same weight with me. After all, a truly great movie transcends time and allows viewers to rediscover its beauty over and over again.

The Ma & Pa Kettle characters were highly popular AND controversial . The films that featured their brood paved the way for future comedic depictions of rural life, with many viewers finding humor in the couple's large family and bumbling ways. However, some critics accused these films of reinforcing negative stereotypes about impoverished and uneducated country people, with Ma & Pa Kettle often being labeled as "hillbillies." Despite these concerns, their films offered a humorous escape for audiences, while subtly showcasing the challenges of rural families struggling through the mid-20th century in America.

The Further Adventures of Ma and Pa Kettle almost seamlessly picks up where The Egg and I left off. For the first solo adventure of the Kettles a new writing team and director is introduced. Leonard Goldstein, associate producer of The Egg and I, was producer of The Further Adventures of Ma and Pa Kettle. With many of the characters played by the same actors and actresses the focus from the MacDonalds to the Kettles works very well. There is a reference to Ma beating Birdie Hicks for first prize at the fair for her quilt, an import scene in The Egg and I.

Almost four years after the Iraq war started and we 're in a bigger hole than ever . That 's not just my opinion; numerous reports, experts, and statistics are supporting this notion. The devastating human and financial toll continue to climb, and the ongoing political instability has worsened despite efforts to establish a semblance of order. Frustration levels both at home and abroad have reached a boiling point. As of today, thousands of lives have been lost and countless communities destroyed, all with no end in sight. This further intensifies the importance of reconsidering our foreign policies, military tactics, and diplomatic relations moving forward.

I could n't believe the eye candy from start to finish . Being a fan of movies directed by music video directors, I knew I was in for a treat. Every single frame was visually stunning and seamlessly integrated with the pulsating rhythms of the exceptional soundtrack. It felt as though my senses were under a relentless, ecstatic bombardment, with rich, kaleidoscopic color palettes blending flawlessly with innovative and often daring cinematography. Moreover, the beautifully synchronized dance sequences brought an entirely new dimension to storytelling, blurring the boundaries between narrative and art, and constantly invigorating the dynamic experience of this utterly mesmerizing film.

I have wracked my brain for another film that reminds me of this one. I really can't come up with one. I think it's because most of the films that take on this topic (war, peace, violence) are in a fixed documentary style.There are some terrific ones out there, all of them better known than USA T.M., I'm sure, but they are intended to be informational and to bring your emotional response to the surface through intellectual means. This DVD, in some ways may seem more intellectual but it really isn't.

Had the pleasure to see this film at the Big Bear Film Festival where it won the Audience Award . I can certainly see why it received the accolade - it was an engaging and impactful watch from start to finish. The direction was flawless, coupled with exceptional cinematography that truly encapsulated the essence of the story. The stellar performances of the cast held the audience captivated and enthralled, making it difficult to pull ourselves away from the screen. It was truly gratifying to see an independent production rise to such great heights at Big Bear.

The Tempest has been interpreted in many different ways ranging from more or less traditional views as dealing with Art to more post-modern approaches that like to dissect the play along post-colonial, feminist, gender or deconstructionist lines. The reason why Jarman's version left me fairly cold is that I didn't have a clue what he was on about. What is the underlying vision/idea/concept behind this rendering of Shakespeare? The previous reviewers do not get much further than revenge tragedy, punk show, but surely there is more to it, isn't there?

This film predates the Australian films Road Warrior and Priscilla of the Desert , and its influence on them is clearly evident. From its stunning visuals to its gripping action, the foundation it set in Australia's cinema landscape cannot be overstated. While it shares some thematic elements with the dystopian world of Road Warrior and the sense of eccentric journey in Priscilla of the Desert, it paved the way for other genre-defying films to flourish. Moreover, it challenged the conventional narrative structure, introduced new filmmaking techniques, and undoubtedly became a major cultural reference that continues to be seen and felt in present Australian cinema.

Based on its current IMDb rating as well as several plot summaries, I didn't expect much from 'Two Hands'. But how wrong I was. From start to finish, you're kept deeply engrossed in a genre which has been continuously unoriginal for quite a while. Even in terms of mise-en-scene and cinematography, the director excels and creates a film consisting of great imagination. If you're looking for a film which is not only entertaining, but also provocative, compelling, and genuinely extraordinary, then make this the next film you watch.

I 'm seen this documentary in its feature-form , in a movie theatre . And ... wouah ! The pictures and cinematography were absolutely stunning! The documentary showcased breathtaking landscapes, intricate details of wildlife, and raw emotion which captivated me from the very beginning. The captivating visuals, paired with a thought-provoking narrative, kept me glued to my seat as I immersed myself in the story that was unfolding before my eyes. Not only did the documentary succeed in raising awareness on a pressing issue, but it also transported me to the very heart of the story.

I thought this film was amazing and I laughed so much that I had to see it twice to catch the bits I missed whilst bending over holding my stomach! The critic who reviewed this film for this site challenged anyone with an IQ over their shoe size to find this film funny, well my IQ is approx:135...I challenge this person to question me and then eat his own words! This film is brilliant and if the critic above wasn't such a boring idiot, he might smile for once in his life and take things as lightly as they're meant!!

Kane is a killer named Jacob Goodnight , he lives in this burned down old hotel , where eight teen agers have dared themselves to explore for a fun Halloween experience. They are unaware of the haunted stories about the building and Jacob's sinister existence. Kane is determined to keep his turf untouched, causing them to become victims of his cruel obsession. As the terrified teenagers wander through the hotel's charred, decrepit halls, they slowly realize the nightmares behind the rumors. Their curiosity fuels the horrifying reemergence of Jacob Goodnight, awakening the demonic presence of Kane, whose twisted hunting instincts challenge the teens to confront their deepest fears.

You will be able to tell within the first 30 seconds of this film whether you want to finish watching it or not. This movie grabs you from the very beginning, showcasing a gripping plot with fascinating characters that pull you into their world. The visuals are stunning, and the unique storytelling quickly absorbs your attention, making the experience feel intense yet enjoyable. The complexity of relationships and emotional depth demonstrated by the actors leave a powerful impact on you. Even if it's not typically a genre you prefer, the brilliant execution and dynamic cinematography make it worth investing your time in, leading to a satisfying, thought-provoking conclusion.

I had no expectations when I started to watch this movie. How surprised I was! This is a great, beautiful, twisted movie which will give your mind a good work-out! It's not simple. If you only enjoy Police Academy style, no-brains movies, this is not for you. The Cell is a deep, complex film with influences from movies like Cube, Silence of the Lambs and The Lawnmower Man, along with lots of completely new ideas. Wonderful, twisted environments, good acting and a compelling story makes this one of the best films I have seen in a long time!

First of all , ignore the comment about how South Park should make fun of Republicans . Everyone is doing that these days. Instead, South Park should remain an unbiased beacon of satirical humor that sheds light on society's absurdities and political extremes from both ends of the spectrum. By staying above the political fray, it has built an empire of thought-provoking comedy which holds nothing sacred, entertaining and enlightening viewers all the while. A simple 'mock-the-Republicans' stint would devalue this ethos, leaving South Park adrift on the ever-growing sea of bias-driven entertainment.

This story has held a special place in my heart for the last thirty-one years. As a boy, I enjoyed stories of mountain men and the wilderness. Books like "Call of the Wild", "White Fang", "The Frontiersman" and "My Side Of the Mountain", influenced me tremendously. I wanted so much to live like a mountain man, but nothing inspired me more to do so, than when I saw this movie on television in 1975. I wanted to be just like "Trapper".

Although dated , this film is definitely worth a watch . I saw it about eight times as a teenager and couldn't get enough of the nostalgia it evoked. The classic soundtrack transports you to another time, while the genuine characters, relationships, and emotions depicted feel as real and raw today as they did when the film was first released. The cinematography and directing make up for the aged visuals and demonstrate the movie's charm and character. In revisiting the film now as an adult, the powerful themes still resonate, serving as an essential piece of cinematic history to be appreciated by viewers across generations.

When I was engaged, my fiance and I would frequent the adult bookstores. He would look for his favorite mags, and on occasion a video that caught the eye. As much as I enjoyed the one-on-one with him that the media caused, there was never a video that I really enjoyed. I had seen only one other movie way back when there was a satellite channel called XXX (it dealt with a private eye unraveling a case) that actually had a proper plot and was enjoyable. All the others were grunting and puffing and blowing and whatnot.

This film, released in 1951, has the usual elements typical of the westerns released during the 50's; the cavalry needing to protect the territory from a murderous band of Indians, an officer determined to see that task through, and the men with him with various character flaws that he has to merge together into a cohesive unit. This small band must hold on to a fort located close to the Indian village until reinforcements arrive. The Indians know, all to well, that the small band is undermanned, and could be wiped out before the help comes.

There's a brand new killer on the loose, and he's doing God's work. Yeah right! This killer makes Jason Voorhes look like a chump, and Freddy Krueger look like a rag doll against this dude. He is Jacob Goodnight(WWE's Glen "KANE" Jacobs), a 7' monster who wields a Axe, and a hook and chain. Those weapons are nothing to him his real finisher is ripping out eyeballs from the victims sockets. That is totally methodical! When the encounter happened 4 years earlier, Jacob killed a rookie cop and maimed the veteran after putting a bullet in his head.

Okay , where to begin . Did you know that the part of the lead robots were offered to famous actors, but they had scheduling conflicts? Yeah, it's true. So, the producers decided to hold open auditions for the role. Hundreds of talented performers lined up for a chance at stardom, bringing their best robotic moves and impressions. But little did they know that there was one surprising contender who managed to impress everyone ‚Äì an AI who used motion capture technology to express perfect robotic mannerisms. Shocking both the producers and the other actors, this artificial intelligence upstaged everyone and secured the lead role.

This show is my absolute favorite. This show is intelligent, entertaining and always full of surprises. Lauren Graham is perfect as Lorelai Gilmore, a single mother who is Rory's best friend. Alexis Bledel shines as the beautiful and intelligent Rory Gilmore and Keiko Agena is one of a kind as Rory's best friend, Lane Kim. I love the witty dialog, it's what makes it unique about the show. Kelly Bishop is wicked great as Emily Gilmore and Edward Herrman is terrific as Richard Gilmore. Scott Patterson is a joy as Luke Danes and the band members are one of a kind to watch.

As a dedicated lover of all things Egyptian this is a classic piece from the 50 's , along with Land of the Pharaohs and The Egyptian, that captures the intrigue and mystique of ancient Egypt. These movies take you on an unforgettable journey through the glorious splendor of a bygone era. Showcasing the rich heritage and majestic structures, they weave tales of love, betrayal, and power struggles. Although not entirely historically accurate, these films provide a glimpse of a fascinating civilization and leave you with an undeniable desire to explore and delve deeper into Egypt's captivating past.

15 Park Avenue, well the name mystifies initially being an address from New York and film being set in Kolkata. However as the story unfolds, one realize the thin line that director tries to walk between Relationships, Social Cause and of course the world of Schizophrenia. I would say Aparna Sen is one director who has so much more to say and has so less time at disposal. Well no doubt she has managed to make a good movie. In a way she makes us realize that probably each one of us is looking for our own '15 Park Avenue'.

This movie is Wonderful! I can watch it again and again. Robin hood is Perfectly cast, and Marian is beautiful. I personally think Marian's German man is the funniest character, along with Latrine and the Sheriff! While space balls got boring and stupid after a while, this one always keeps your interest! W O N D E R F U L This was a great film, and never gets boring. A great cast is in the roles, and it is spoofed perfectly, and makes so much sense, and can be watched again and again!

Flawless writing and brilliant acting make this unusually delightful and witty plot-twister one of the best American films I have ever had the pleasure of watching. With a meticulously crafted script that deftly navigates the realms of suspense and humor, it creates an enthralling cinematic experience that thoroughly engages the audience from start to finish. The razor-sharp dialogue, accompanied by perfectly timed comedic beats and outstanding performances from the ensemble cast, makes every character feel distinct and relatable. Their effortless chemistry only elevates the viewing experience, propelling the plot with masterful pacing and tension.

I had no idea who Bruce Haack was before seeing this film . I had just seen the MOOG doc umentary and was hungry for more insight into the world of electronic music pioneers. "The King of Techno" is an affectionate, in-depth exploration of Bruce Haack's life and music, introducing audiences to an unsung hero of the industry. Born and raised in a remote part of Canada, he showed an aptitude for both music and invention, eventually creating groundbreaking electronic instruments that continue to impact modern music today. Fascinating archival footage combined with engaging interviews provides an engrossing narrative about an oft-overlooked yet important figure.

As a European, the movie is a nice throwback to my time as a student in the 1980's and the experiences I had living abroad and interacting with other nationalities, although the circumstances were slightly different.
