Klapisch (the director) went to the New York Film School from 1982-85, so one would think that he is drawing on this experience.It is interesting how the film balances the message that "one should not generalize" with the notion that "for every stereotype, there is some underlying truth". For example, the Italian character is based more on the pothead aspect than on any well-known Italian stereotype.

* * SPOILERS AHEAD * * It is really unfortunate that a movie so well produced turns out to besuch a letdown in the end. With its all-star cast and high production value, one would expect it to live up to the hype, but ultimately it fell short. The plot, although engaging in the beginning, ultimately becomes confusing and unconvincing, and certain plot twists feel unnecessary or underdeveloped. Some may appreciate the movie's bold attempts to break traditional molds, but it's a shame the innovative direction it takes gets weighed down by underwhelming plot lines and character arcs.

Having read the other comment about this superb piece of TV drama I felt compelled to balance things a little . It is undeniable that the craftsmanship and storytelling showcased in this production are of top-notch quality. The script was filled with intricate plotlines, well-developed characters, and meaningful dialogues that showcased the creativity of the writers. Moreover, the cast was phenomenal, giving heartfelt and passionate performances, effortlessly drawing the viewer into the narrative. Coupled with skillful direction, cinematography, and sound design, the drama effectively captured and portrayed the emotional depths of the story.

Being an avid Carpenter Fan, I really loved this film (although the wigs do leave a lot to be desired!) and agree with many of the comments, that certain areas of her life were absent or not touched on. Whatever - it leaves your curiosity well and truly unsatisfied, so off I went to discover more. I must recommend a book by Ray Coleman - Carpenters - The Untold Story. The book is an intelligent read and unlike the film, is 'real' and down to earth. I hope you enjoy it. I remember Cynthia Gibb from her days in Fame and Gypsy.

See No Evil With Kane . The Movie Has a great storyline But it just was n't a Hide my eyes and shiver film. "See No Evil with Kane" is a movie that strives to thrill and entertain its audience by weaving a captivating tale without being overly graphic. Kane's phenomenal performance, coupled with the skilled direction, perfectly blends suspense, emotion, and the battle of good vs evil. Though it doesn't feature gruesome violence or heart-stopping scares, the film successfully instills an unnerving sense of fear and paranoia, thanks to its well-structured pacing and eerie atmosphere.

I caught this flick on the trail end of a tape I had used to capture a movie I truly wanted to wanted to see again. When I saw Raquel Welch's name in the opening credits, I decided to watch it. It was actually mildly entertaining, and took me back "in the wayback machine" to the farcical movies that Hollywood churned out during the sixties, much in the same genre as the current Austin Powers stuff. Oh the acting was not superb, nor was the plot, but it was worth watching.

Craig Brewer is now officially a writer/director for whom I will see any film by, no matter how bad it may look. His debut, Hustle and Flow, was one of my favorites from that year, with its emotionally charged storyline and realistic, fallible characters. I wasn't quite sure what I would end up thinking after seeing this sophomore effort. The cast seemed great, the trailer used music effectively, however, it seemed like there was a good chance it would cross into absurdity, and fast. Fortunately, Black Snake Moan hits all its marks dead-on.

Renee Zellweger absolutely shines as Nurse Betty , easily one of the most charming , off-beat , and lighthearted comedies in recent memory. Set against the backdrop of a small Midwestern town, the film perfectly blends quirky humor and heartfelt sentiment as we follow Nurse Betty on her delightfully unexpected adventures. Supported by a well-rounded cast, including the likes of Chris Rock and Greg Kinnear, the film demonstrates each character's endearing nuances, further captivating audiences. So if you're looking to add a sprinkle of heart-warming fun to your movie repertoire, look no further than the undeniable allure of Nurse Betty.

I love to see a female protagonist, in this movie her name was Rose. Rose brought out a lot of interesting questions in her journey of fulfillment.Is is possible to attain peace and internal fulfillment through external means? Does our society teach this? Can one be a victim of memory which may lead to victimizing others? Is one responsible for being a product of one's environment? To what extent can one control or take control of one's environment? How is a "typical" human alike or different than Rose? Lastly, would the outcome or story change if it were from another country like France or Italy?

Personally , I regard `` The Egyptian '' in an extremely favourable light.It was introduced to me by a well-known Egyptologist during a trip to the captivating country of Egypt. The story weaves a stunning tapestry of historical fact, cultural nuance and emotive power, leaving me not only engaged, but also transported into a different time and space. The protagonist's intriguing journey provides valuable insights into ancient Egyptian life, customs and beliefs, which help deepen my appreciation of this captivating culture. The descriptive language employed by the author vividly depicts the intricacies of life at the time, effortlessly captivating my imagination.

This film was made soon enough after Karen's passing that perhaps Richard Carpenter and the people closest to Karen were feeling a little guilty as to how they may have contributed to her health problems. As the years have passed (almost 25 to be exact) it must have gotten easier to deny any complicity. Richard has spent the years after Karen's death endlessly remixing and recompiling the recordings he made with her. He married his cousin, Mary, and from what I have read, it looks like he may be planning a next generation Carpenters with his children.

I had no expectations when I started to watch this movie . How surprised I was ! This is a masterpiece that absolutely captivated me from the very beginning. The plot is compelling, rich, and well-developed, pulling you in and never letting you go. The characters are memorable and expertly portrayed by an incredible cast that breathed life into every scene. The visuals are stunning, complemented by a mesmerizing score that sets the perfect tone for this cinematic journey. As the credits rolled, I was left speechless, reflecting on the powerful message conveyed throughout the movie.

Gosh , I am learning pretty fast that sometimes when you see a film as a youngster and then again as an adult, your perspectives on it can drastically change. What I once considered to be an exciting, entertaining movie is now revealing itself to be rather shallow or cheesy upon a recent viewing. The nostalgia is certainly there, but as my tastes and critical eye have evolved, I have discovered that certain aspects of the plot are overly simplistic, the character development may be lacking, and the special effects less impressive than they once appeared.

Well, okay, maybe not perfect, but it was pretty close. This movie jumped from crime drama to romantic goofball comedy and back again so quickly all the way throughout that it seemed like two different movies that played simultaneously and then joined up again at the end. But they did it smoothly, and some in the theater found the bloody parts (like the scalping scene) to be funny as well. I just about threw up, but I guess that's just me. Greg Kinear is perfect as a soap opera actor.

How can anyone DARE say anything BAD about this film ? Pardon Mel Brooks for being a brilliant comedian and satirist, taking jabs at various genres and making people laugh until their sides hurt. Can we not appreciate the immense talent, wit, and thought put into creating something that holds up to scrutiny while still making us laugh hysterically? Perhaps it is a personal inability to understand the unique genius that permeates this film, but if one were to allow themselves to appreciate it for the mastery of comedic skill displayed, they might be able to see its true brilliance.

In one of the many Bugs Bunny-Daffy Duck cartoons, Elmer Fudd is out hunting, and Daffy tries to get him to shoot Bugs. Needless to say, Bugs has his own agenda. Moreover, "Rabbit Seasoning" makes interesting use of word order and pronouns (warning: it just might hilariously and royally mess up your speech).I think that probably my favorite aspect of this cartoon is the costumes worn by Bugs and Daffy. One of them seems like it would have been risqu√© for 1952 (especially in a cartoon), but they pull it off perfectly, as they always did.

This second full-length Lone Ranger feature does n't measure up to the 1956 classic but is a fine film with a good plot and respectable performances. It falls short of capturing the magic of the original, yet still manages to hold its own with enjoyable action sequences and admirable cinematography. In this adaptation, we follow the masked vigilante and his trusty sidekick, Tonto, as they combat evil and seek justice in a Western frontier setting. While the overall character development may lack depth, the film remains true to its classic origins with nostalgia-inducing themes of camaraderie, heroism, and a desire to stand up against corruption.

***SPOILERS*** ***SPOILERS*** THE CELL / (2000) **** (out of four)"Do you believe there is a part of yourself, deep inside in your mind, with things you don't want other people to see? During a session when I'm inside, I get to see those things." --Catherine DeaneAnd so do we. One of the most visually stimulating films of the year, "The Cell" is a love/hate movie-either you love it or you hate it.

Gilmore Girls is one of the funniest, most clever, sharp-witted, sarcastic and heart-warming television shows I've ever watched, (second only to my most favorite television show of all time, F*R*I*E*N*D*S). The quick pace and many pop-culture references can leave some viewers confused, but once you catch on to the ways of the Gilmores, you'll be hooked for life. Just some random comments, I recently (finally) began watching Season 6 and wow! It's one of my favorite seasons so far.

1981's Just Before Dawn is one of the best tales of wilderness horror out there. It's one of the finest-made slashers of the 80's and it easily blows movies like The Final Terror, Don't Go in the Woods, or The Prey out of the water.A group of young adults come to check out the mountain property that one of the group has just bought. However they are not alone in the wild. A hulking in-bred murderer, who seems to be in two places at once, is lurking and apparently hates trespassers.

`` L'Auberge Espagnole '' collected the audience wherever it was shown . It gathered audience awards on many film festivals across the globe, garnering widespread acclaim from critics and viewers alike. This international success led to increased demand for foreign language films and boosted the visibility of emerging talent. "L'Auberge Espagnole" broke boundaries, bridging cultural divides through its relatable characters and engaging narrative, effectively solidifying its status as a beloved classic. The movie's themes of cultural diversity, self-discovery, and the powerful bonds formed between the characters transcended language barriers, capturing the hearts of people from various backgrounds, proving cinema truly is a universal medium.

`` Stripperella '' is an animated series about a girl named Erotica Jones ( voiced by Pamela Anderson ) who works as a stripper by night and a crime-fighting superhero by day. The series is set in the fictional city of Angleterre, where she uses her beauty, brains, and sexual prowess to take down various criminals and threats. Along with her trusty sidekick, the horny Professor Sturges, Stripperella fights foes like Dr. Cesarean, a plastic surgeon who specializes in unrequested and botched procedures, or Pushy Galore, who uses mind control to turn customers into shopping addicts.

Forget about Donnie Darko . I open with this because it seems that a good portion of the reviews I 've read on this site constantly compare other mind-bending films to that cult classic. The truth is, every film has its own merits and should be treated as a separate entity. For example, David Lynch's work takes the viewers on a cerebral journey, incorporating eerie atmospheres and surreal storylines, making his style unique to him. Likewise, Charlie Kaufman is known for delving into intricate human relationships while layering them with otherworldly ideas.

George Cukor is and always will be one of my favorites . The unsung hero of his generation . Nobody could quite match the elegant and refined style of his films, combined with a flair for capturing genuine human emotion. His impact on the Golden Age of Hollywood is undeniable, directing some of the most celebrated and memorable films of his era such as The Philadelphia Story, My Fair Lady, and A Star is Born. His distinctive directing methods left an indelible mark on classic cinema and continued to influence future generations of filmmakers.

My favorite film this year . Great characters and plot , and the direction and editing was smooth , visually stunning, and seamless. This cinematic gem had a powerful, compelling narrative that kept me on the edge of my seat, while the flawless performances from the cast made every moment memorable and engaging. The film expertly managed to balance emotion, action, and humor, never taking itself too seriously, and staying fresh throughout its runtime. The striking cinematography and riveting score also significantly enhanced the overall experience, ultimately making this not just my favorite film of the year, but an unforgettable and remarkable viewing journey.

I ca n't help but notice the negative reviews this movie has gotten . To be honest , I saw the film without reading any of these reviews and I absolutely loved it. The plot was intriguing, the performances by the actors were exceptional, and the cinematography was top-notch. I believe that a large portion of the negative feedback may stem from the viewers having unreasonably high expectations, comparing this movie to legendary blockbusters. The thing with art, including movies, is that it's subjective; different people resonate with different works.

I'm seen this documentary in its feature-form, in a movie theatre. And... wouah! The pictures are astonishing, one really wonder how by Jove did they manage to film those waves, those animals, those... is that a plant ? a predator ? a creature from the movie Abbyss ? Anyway, it's remarkable. Sure we've seen a lot of such documentary on TV, with weird animals and so on, but none with such a beauty, a precision, a deep emotion. The only downside is the commentary.

First of all - I hardly ever watch Swedish movies, and this is actually the second time in my life I watch a Swedish movie on cinema! Therefor, I believe it's one of the best Swedish movies ever! The combination of thrill and humour is OUTSTANDING, and sometimes you don't even know if you should be terrified or just laugh! The plot is about this man, a writer who wants to go to Germany after World War II and help the Germans to start over. On the way to Germany, he is trying to help his friends on the train, which is however a bad idea.

Gregory Peck and Gig Young are competing for the same girl and after Peck sends Young on a very dangerous mission, they blame him for his reasons. Feeling guilty, Peck goes on an almost impossible task of defending a fort, where they are outnumbered by the Indians. Peck chooses for this mission soldiers which he considers to be the scum of the earth and the actors that play these soldiers, Ward Bond, Lon Chaney Jr., Neville Brand among others, are excellent. The script is derived from a novel by Charles Marquis Warren who was a specialist in westerns, as a writer, director and producer.

Just Before Dawn is one of those really good slashers that send chills down your spine every time you watch it. The film masterfully combines spine-tingling suspense with gruesome gore, truly capturing the essence of classic horror. Set in a remote forest, a group of friends unknowingly ventures into the hunting ground of a twisted killer, who terrorizes the campers relentlessly throughout the night. The film manages to create a menacing atmosphere from the start, featuring heart-stopping jumpscares, chilling sequences and eerily unsettling silence. Strong performances from the cast members, authentic and realistic fear displayed throughout, provide the sense of impending doom.

This is the best movie I have ever seen . It has it all tragedy and happiness love and hate . The plot is incredibly well-crafted, with engaging twists that keep you guessing till the end. The characters are wonderfully developed, each having their own unique quirks and emotional depth, making them relatable and human. The stunning visuals and carefully composed soundtrack create an atmosphere that grips you from the opening scene, immersing you into the rollercoaster ride of emotions that follows. It beautifully captures the essence of life itself, exploring themes of friendship, family, ambition, and the power of love over adversity.

Almost 20 years before Frank Marshall brought tears to your eyes with his mesmerizing epic `` Alive '' , there was a lesser-known but equally compelling survival drama that captivated audiences around the globe. Released in 1972, the harrowing tale, "Desperate Journeys," follows a group of lost adventurers in the harsh and unforgiving terrain of the Andes mountains. Through acts of courage, human endurance, and unwavering perseverance, this story pushed the limits of emotional storytelling, connecting viewers with the plight of each desperate soul fighting to survive the challenges they face, and proving the limitless strength and resilience of the human spirit.
